prompt: What are the elements of the Mitigation of Damages (Personal Injury)?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Enhance a defense Claimant must take reasonable actions to limit or keep down any damages caused by a breach or wrongful act and, if appropriate, cannot recover those damages.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"These are the elements of mitigation of damages (personal injury):          - Injured plaintiff responsible for tried to reduce damages from injury    - Plaintiff's actions are compared to a \"reasonable person\" in the same situation     - Failure to try to reduce damages can reduce recovery","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Answer: The elements of mitigation of damages in a personal injury case require that the plaintiff:         - Take reasonable action to limit the costs related to damages, which could include       a) Getting medical care when injured (even if you aren't sure if you were hurt badly), or    b) Getting a different or less expensive job if your injury prevents you from working your regular job; and         - Not take unreasonable action to increase the costs related to damages, which could include       a) Continuing to not get medical care after being hurt under circumstances that make it apparent that such care is needed; or     b)  Going on an expensive vacation to make yourself feel better after being hurt.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Even if you are found to be injured from the actions of another (the defendant), you cannot simply sit back and allow damage to accumulate. You are legally bound to make sure that you do what you can to keep your damages from becoming worse. This is called the \"mitigation of damages.\"     If you are claiming damages for personal injury, the elements of the duty to mitigate damages include:       - You must seek medical advice and follow doctor's orders unless they are unreasonable.    - You must not take any action that would aggravate your injury.       Public Citizen's Litigation Group","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Mitigation of Damages - Personal Injuries      Mitigation of damages means that when a plaintiff has an injury, the law assumes that the plaintiff uses reasonable efforts to avoid making the injury worse. This means that the plaintiff must accept reasonable treatment for the injuries or other damages caused by the defendant. The costs of such treatment are included in the amount of the damages award. \"Reasonable efforts\" means efforts that are not dangerous or otherwise beyond what one would expect under the circumstances. A broken leg is painful and is probably not worse if someone refuses to have surgery. If surgery is too risky or dangerous, it is not unreasonable to refuse it.    When you have a personal injury, it is your responsibility to do what you can to keep the damage from getting worse. When you consider treatment, there are many things to take into account including the cost and potential side effects. A lawyer can help you evaluate treatments that have been recommended beyond the immediate First Aid or emergency treatment.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Mitigation of damages is a doctrine in the law of damages that states that a plaintiff may not recover for damages that he could have reasonably avoided. This principle has roots in the common law of England. Under the doctrine, a plaintiff must take reasonable action to minimize the amount of damages caused by a defendant, and a plaintiff cannot collect damages for any avoidable loss in excess of that amount. For example, an employee who is unfairly terminated from employment must make reasonable efforts to find a comparable replacement job in order to mitigate his or her damages. If the employee is able to find a comparable replacement job, then he or she may only recover damages equal to the difference in pay over the period between jobs. A case with a similar fact pattern is Sims v. General Motors Corp., 839 F. Supp. 184 5th Cir. 1993.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is the principle of Damages From Multiple Defendants?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If a plaintiff's damages are caused by more than one person, the plaintiff may recover from each and every one of them. The amount each defendant pays is up to the jury. It usually depends on the degree of fault of each defendant.     For example, a jury finds that Ms. Y owes Mr. X $200,000 for damages he suffered in an auto accident. If there were two defendants, the jury may decide that the first is 60 percent at fault and the second is 40 percent at fault. Each defendant then pays according to his degree of fault. The first pays $120,000, which is 60 percent of $200,000. The second pays $80,000, which is 40 percent of $200,000.     In other cases each defendant may be responsible for the full amount of the damages. This is called joint and several liability. It means that the plaintiff may recover the entire amount of the loss from any one of the defendants, regardless of that defendant's share of the fault. If the defendant who pays the full amount does so, then he may have the right to obtain part of the money back from the other defendants.     The kind of liability a court applies varies according to the state.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If two or more people wrongfully cause you harm, their financial liability to you can be based on either \"joint and several liability\" or \"several liability.\" These are two different methods of determining the liability of the wrongdoers.    Joint and several liability      Under joint and several liability, all the wrongdoers can be sued together as a group or each can be sued individually.    If the wrongdoers are sued together, a court or jury will decide how much the injured party should recover. That amount may be divided among the wrongdoers according to the amount of blame they have or fixed equally. If one or more wrongdoers cannot or do not pay their part of the damages, the rest must pay the difference.     If the wrongdoers are sued individually, the injured party must prove in each case the damages caused to him/her. If the wrongdoers are not equally liable, the financial liability of a wrongdoer may be more than the liability of other wrongdoers, depending on how much the court or jury finds a wrongdoer contributed to the damage. Under joint and several liability, if other wrongdoers cannot or do not pay their share, the wrongdoer must pay the difference.    The advantage to the injured person is that joint and several liability increases the likelihood that the injured party will be able to recover all the damages to which he or she is entitled. Joint and several liability is the traditional method used in most courts.     Several liability     Under several liability, each wrongdoer is responsible only for the amount of damage that he or she caused. If the wrongdoers are sued together as a group, the amount of damage is divided between them according to the amount of blame they have. If the wrongdoers are sued individually, the court or jury determines the liability of each wrongdoer separately.    The advantage to the wrongdoers is that several liability limits their financial liability if other wrongdoers cannot or will not pay their share of damages.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If there is more than one defendant in a case, the court must determine whether the defendants are jointly and severally liable. If the defendants are jointly and severally liable, the injured plaintiff can obtain the entire amount of the damages owed to him or her from any one of the defendants or, if they wish, from a combination of the defendants. For example, if the plaintiff was awarded $1,000,000 in damages, the plaintiff could seek to collect the entire amount from any one defendant. Even if the plaintiff collects the entire amount of damages from one defendant, the others remain liable to pay their share of the damages. If a defendant pays more than his or her share, she or he can require the others to pay their share, usually through a separate action, known as contribution. If the defendants are not jointly and severally liable, the plaintiff can seek to collect only from each defendant an amount equal to each defendant's percentage responsibility. For example, if the plaintiff was awarded $1,000,000 in damages and was severely injured in an accident caused by two defendants, the plaintiff could seek to collect only a maximum of $500,000 from each defendant. If the plaintiff collected $500,000 from one defendant, the plaintiff may not recover from the other defendant.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When several people cause you harm, you may have to sue them jointly (together) or severally (separately). Joint and several liabilities means that if you sue several people, and one of them cannot pay, the others have to pay the whole amount. The amount paid to you is called damages.     For example, if three people joined in causing injuries to you, you might sue all three of them at once (jointly). If you were awarded $100,000 in damages but one was unable to pay his share, you could try to collect the entire judgment from the other two defendants.    Joint and several liabilities often apply to products liability lawsuits, lawsuits against several negligent drivers, and actions against partners in partnerships. Joint and several liability does not apply if each person caused a separate and different injury to you. In this case, a judgment against one person has no effect on your claim against the others.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If more than one party is at fault, each one is jointly and severally liable for the full amount of the damages. This rule applies whether the parties were jointly at fault, or if only one party was actually to blame but the injured person cannot collect from that party. Joint and several liability ensures that an injured person will be able to collect all of his or her damages. Then, if necessary, a defendant who pays more than his or proportionate share may sue the other defendants to recover the difference.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What are the elements of the Damages on Multiple Legal Theories?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"How to Request a Jury Trial on the Issue of Damages       A demand for a jury trial on the issue of damages may be made at the time the complaint is filed, or within 20 days after service of an answer or other responsive pleading. If no timely demand for jury trial is made, the issue of damages shall be tried to the court. The demand shall be endorsed upon the complaint, or upon a separate paper and attached to the complaint. If it is not so endorsed on the complaint when it is served, a copy of the demand shall be served on the adverse party at or before the time of serving the summons and complaint upon such party. See M.R.Civ. P. 38.   Urging the Court to Grant the Request for a Jury Trial       If a timely demand for jury trial has been made, the trial shall be by jury, unless (1) the parties agree to a non-jury trial; or (2) the court, upon motion or on its own initiative, orders a non-jury trial. See M.R.Civ. P. 38. If the jury trial demanded relates to an issue not triable of right by a jury, the court may, in its discretion, grant a jury trial. If the relief sought is legal and equitable, the jury trial may not be denied (except for good cause).   Multiple Legal Theories       When a plaintiff alleges more than one legal theory in its complaint, the plaintiff may recover on any one of the theories, as long as it has the burden of proof and the court finds in its favor. When a plaintiff sues on more than one legal theory, a separate claim should be commenced and maintained on each theory. It is the substance of the complaint that determines which provision of the Rule applies. In the complaint, the plaintiff specifically requested a jury trial on the issue of damages for breach of contract. Under these circumstances, the party may recover on the issue of damages, even though the jury ultimately concluded the breach had not been justified.     See the Courts page for information about contacts for each court.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Key points regarding damages on multiple legal theories include:       - When a judgment is recovered on more than one legal theory, it cannot include duplicative elements of recovery.    - The key to avoiding duplicative elements of recovery is to ensure that the verdict is adequate for each legal theory.    - When a judgment is for more than one legal theory and the amount awarded is adequate for each legal theory, the amount of the appeal bond must be reduced by stipulation or by the court.       These key points are from Chapter 6 - Award and Recovery of Damages and are not intended to be legal advice.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

If a party obtains a judgment on more than one legal theory, the court must ensure that the party does not recover twice for the same item of damages. This requires the court to aggregate the damages awarded on the various theories to make sure that when it awards the total it does not award any item of damage twice. On the other hand, where a party is entitled to damages under various theories, the court should award the damages to which the party is entitled in the appropriate amount although the theories permitting recovery are similar.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you decide that a person is entitled to recover damages for breach of contract or for injury to property, the amount of money that you award must compensate the person for the loss. It may include the loss of use of the money that would have been received if the contract had not been breached, or if the property had not been injured. This compensation is called \"prejudgment interest\".    If the trial took place in Newport News, Norfolk, Portsmouth, or Chesapeake and you find that the defendant had notice that the claim was being or would be presented to a court, you must also award prejudgment interest on the amount of money you find the plaintiff is entitled to recover. You must use a rate of 10 percent per year.    In other trial locations you may award prejudgment interest on the amount of money you find the plaintiff is entitled to recover. prompt: What is the legal standard for the Punitive Damagesâ€”Individual Defendantâ€”Trial Not Bifurcated?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The federal legal standard for punitive damages is set by the Supreme Court in BMW v. Gore. The BMW decision sets three guideposts for determining whether a punitive damage award is grossly excessive:  (1) the degree of reprehensibility of the defendants conduct;  (2) the disparity between the actual or potential harm suffered by the plaintiff and the punitive damages award; and  (3) the difference between the punitive damages awarded by the jury and the civil penalties authorized or imposed in comparable cases. These guideposts are designed to enforce a constitutional limit on punitive damages under the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.   Some states have additional rules regarding punitive damages and civil rights claims. For example, some states cap the amount of punitive damages in civil rights claims.   In Nike v. Kasky, the Supreme Court held,  A Compensatory Damage Award Cannot Punish Defendants for Injuring Non-Parties Where Plaintiffs Failed to Prove They Suffered Actual Injury Directly Caused by the Defendants. Results of surveys that reveal how much people value the interest protected by a law, when there is no evidence that plaintiffs suffered injury or that defendants' conduct caused an injury, cannot support an award of compensatory damages.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What does Punitive Damagesâ€”Individual Defendantâ€”Bifurcated Trial (Second Phase) require under the law?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Punitive Damagesâ€”Individual Defendantâ€”Bifurcated Trial (Second Phase) provides the United States legal standard for imposing punitive damages. The clause establishes a two-part process for deciding punitive damages, separating the process for deciding if there were compensatory damages from the process for deciding if punitive damages are appropriate. This is called a bifurcated trial. In the first part, the jury decides whether the defendant is liable, and if so, what amount of monetary damages to award to compensate the individual for a loss or injury. This award of damages is called compensatory damages. In the second part, the jury decides whether to impose punitive damages. If it decides to impose punitive damages, it must also decide the amount of punitive damages to impose.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The jury's role in deciding whether to impose punitive damages. After deciding whether to find actual damages and how much actual damages to award, and (in a case based on a defective product) determining who should be held liable, the jury may be asked to decide whether to award punitive damages, and if so, how much to award. In most cases, determining whether to award punitive damages and the amount of any punitive damages must be done in a separate portion of the trial than that for deciding liability and awarding actual damages. This separate portion is called a \"bifurcated trial.\"  Under federal law, punitive damages may be awarded only if the defendant's conduct was \"motivated by evil motive or intent,\" or \"involves reckless or callous indifference to the federally protected rights of others.\" The amount of the punitive damages may be no more than $250,000; $350,000; or $1,000,000 depending on whether the case involves a small business, a corporation that had fewer than 500 employees, or corporations that had 500 or more employees. These limits apply to cases against an individual defendant only.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"In cases brought in federal court, courts try different issues separately in different phases. This is called a bifurcated trial. The order of the phases is usually agreed to by the parties or decided by the judge. One issue that is often tried in a separate phase is punitive damages.    Under federal law, in the punitive damage phase, the defendant cannot present evidence or argument that would reduce the amount of the damages award. For example, the defendant cannot present evidence that the plaintiff's misconduct contributed to the loss because this would defeat the purpose of punitive damages. prompt: What does Punitive Damagesâ€”Entity Defendantâ€”Bifurcated Trial (first Phase) require under the law?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"These instructions are to help you decide whether the plaintiff is entitled to recover punitive damages from the entity defendant (such as a corporation, governmental body or other organization). Punitive damages are damages, additional to actual damages, which may be awarded to punish a defendant for malicious or egregious wrongdoing and to deter similar conduct in the future.    Under the law, the trial of punitive damages must be bifurcated (split in two). The first phase deals with a determination of whether the plaintiff is entitled to recover punitive damages. This phase does not consider the amount of punitive damages to be awarded. If you decide that the plaintiff is entitled to recover punitive damages, you will be asked to report that verdict in the appropriate place on the verdict form. The second phase deals with the amount of punitive damages.    As the limiting instructions have stated, punitive damages are not to be awarded to punish a defendant who was merely negligent or grossly negligent. To justify an award of punitive damages, the defendant must have acted with actual malice, actual fraud, intent to deceive, willful and wanton misconduct, or reckless disregard for the rights of others. In addition, to recover punitive damages the plaintiff must establish actual damages.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Punitive damages are awarded against a defendant to punish the defendant for intentional wrong or to set an example so that the defendant or others do not do it again. The award of punitive damages does not require a economic injury or loss. You may award punitive damages only if you individually agree that the plaintiff has proved by clear and convincing evidence that the defendant acted out of anger or ill will or in a wanton or reckless manner. Cross out the statement with which you do not agree.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"These instructions are about punitive damages. Punitive damages are meant to punish a defendant for malicious or reckless behavior and to deter that defendant and others like it from behaving the same way. You may award punitive damages only if the plaintiff proves by clear and convincing evidence that the defendant acted with malice or evil motive or that the defendant's conduct was outrageous. There is a limit on the amount of punitive damages that may be awarded. Punitive damages may be awarded only in a portion of the trial that is proved separately from the portion of the trial on actual damages. These are called 'bifurcated' trials. prompt: Which case relates to Punitive Damagesâ€”Entity Defendantâ€”Bifurcated Trial (first Phase)?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bifurcation of a trial on punitive damages may also be required under certain circumstances, including that  the defendant's liability for compensatory damages has been established by a prior judgment or verdict, or the trial court determines the issue may be conveniently tried separately. Studies have found that the presence of punitive damages may bias a jury's evaluation of the evidence pertaining to compensatory damages. For this reason, bifurcating a trial into a liability and punitive damages phase is often used to reduce bias in the jury's decision on compensatory damages liability and to lessen the cost and length of a trial when there is no finding of liability. A bifurcated trial on punitive damages protects against a denial of due process and constitutes an essential procedural safeguard. The bifurcation of a punitive damages claim is not the exclusive method for addressing bias; courts may use other methods, such as the courts screening the evidence for bias before the case goes to the jury.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"You must provide appropriate jury instructions to explain the law. The following is part of a larger instruction on punitive damages and individual and entity defendants. It explains that trial is not bifurcated and that you are to consider compensatory damages and punitive damages together. You may use it as part of your instructions to the jury.    \"You have previously heard my instructions about compensatory damages. Punitive damages are different from \"compensatory\" damages. Compensatory damages are intended to compensate a person injured by others' wrongful conduct. Punitive damages, on the other hand, are intended to punish persons who engage in such conduct and to deter them and others from engaging in similar conduct.       You will decide the issue of compensatory damages at the same time you decide the issue of punitive damages. Accordingly, if you find that the defendant is liable and that the plaintiff is entitled to compensatory damages, then you must also decide whether the defendant's wrongful conduct warrants an award of punitive damages.\"    Please note that this is part of a larger instruction on punitive damages and individual and entity defendants and should be used together with the other parts of the instruction.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is the principle of Punitive Damagesâ€”Individual and Corporate Defendants (Corporate Liability Based on Acts of Named Individual)â€”Bifurcated Trial (first Phase)?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Punitive damages are damages awarded against a defendant over and above the amount of compensatory damages. The intent of punitive damages is to punish the defendant for intentional wrongdoing and to deter similar bad conduct in the future.    To award punitive damages against a corporation or other entity, the plaintiff has to prove that the defendant engaged in conduct that was authorized or ratified by a corporate officer, manager, or managing agent or involved a pattern or practice of malice or oppression. Ratification means that a corporate officer, manager, or managing agent knew what was going on and did nothing to stop it including the power to stop what was going on.    In California, the determination of whether punitive damages will be awarded is a separate trial from the trial to determine liability and compensatory damages. If the jury finds by clear and convincing evidence that a defendant is liable for punitive damages and that the alleged conduct was committed by or engaged in under the authority or ratification of a responsible corporate officer or managing agent or was a part of a pattern or practice of malice or oppression, then the court will conduct a trial to determine the amount of the punitive damage award.     United States Courts, Punitive Damages, http://www.uscourts.gov/about-federal-courts/court-role-and-structure/courts-and-mediation-dispute-resolution/punitive-damages","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The defendant may be \"an individual, a partnership, a corporation, or any other legal entity.\" Allegations of wrongdoing against the defendant may be made by more than one plaintiff, and the plaintiffs may seek relief against the defendant for more than one \"violation.\" A \"violation\" may be any act that may be legally considered a \"wrong\": actions which are illegal because they violate a statute or regulation, are criminal, are based on negligence or malpractice, or which violate the legal rights of others due to the existence of a contract, \"a relationship of trust and confidence,\" or other special circumstances.  When a party to a case alleges claims for \"punitive damages,\" under the law \"there must be a hearing for a determination of whether punitive damages will be awarded.\" The hearing may be at the same time as \"an adjudication of liability\" and the amount of \"such damages.\" Or the hearing may be \"bifurcated,\" meaning the adjudication of liability and the amount of punitive damages will be tried separately.  When a case involves \"a claim for punitive damages against a corporation,\" it may be that the same case involves both the corporation itself and also a \"Named Individual\" who is or was an officer, director, or employee of the corporation. These two parties are separately and individually considered to be defendants. Absent further stipulation, each defendant has the right to an impartial jury. If a case involves more than one defendant, if any defendant is a corporation, and if the parties agree, all of the issues in the case may be tried to one jury.  Typically a bifurcated trial involves two phases. The first phase addresses whether the defendant is liable, or legally responsible for committing the alleged positive act or omission, or violating the legal duty, under the law. In this phase, among other questions, the jury will determine whether the defendant acted with \"actual malice,\" in \"reckless disregard\" of a \"high risk\" that others could be harmed by the defendant's actions, or with \"oppression, fraud or malice.\" Actual malice is traditionally defined as the \"intent to do an injury\" to another. It is purposely doing harm, or \"knowing that one's conduct is harmful, or being subjectively reckless in avoiding that knowledge.\" Malice, in a more general sense, is \"ill will, spite, hatred, or a desire to harm another, either because of a hostile impulse or from a sense of injury.\"","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

However, several cases discuss bifurcation in general. Holt v. Halperin, 755 F.2d 797, 800 (11th Cir. 1985), establishes four criteria the court should apply before bifurcating trial issues: the controlling of prejudice, avoiding a waste of time and effort, judicial economy, and the avoidance of inconsistent results. These criteria should be applied to determine how to conduct a punitive damages trial, i.e. how to separate factual and legal issues to avoid repetition of evidence. In Rojas v. Florida, 285 F.3d 1339 (11th Cir. 2002), the Eleventh Circuit Court noted, in categorically approving bifurcation of the punitive damages trial, that under Florida law the separate phases of the trial may differ depending on the basis for the punitive damages. When based on the defendant's conduct, the second phase centers on the finding of malice or actual intent. prompt: How is Comparative Fault of Plaintiffâ€”General Verdict explained to the jury?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Comparative Fault of Plaintiffâ€\"General Verdict is a simple form of verdict that requires only a finding of general issues in the liability phase. This means that the questions answered will include: Did the plaintiff prove the elements of his/her case? Was the plaintiff negligent? Was the defendant negligent? Did the plaintiff suffer damages? or Were the plaintiff's damages caused by the defendant's negligence? The jury may be asked to find a percentage of fault of any person or entity in the answer to the question dealing with negligence. This percentage is used to calculate the amount of the verdict as explained in the jury instruction on comparative fault. The jury may be asked to answer some of these questions in the damage phase.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"New Jersey's Model Jury Charges provide the following general verdict instruction on comparative fault of plaintiff. You have found that defendant is negligent. By that, I mean that you have found that defendant breached a duty owed to plaintiff. A duty is a legal obligation. Breach of a duty is the failure to perform that duty properly. Breach of a duty may also be called negligence.  Negligence alone is not enough to allow plaintiff to recover. You must also find that the defendant's negligence was a legal cause of plaintiff's harm. Something is a legal cause of an event if the event would not have happened but for it; nothing else prevents the cause from producing the event; and the cause is relevant.  You have found that the plaintiff was negligent also. By that, I mean that you have found that plaintiff breached a duty which he or she owed to him or herself. A duty is a legal obligation. Breach of a duty is the failure to perform that duty properly. Breach of a duty may also be called negligence.  Plaintiff's negligence may reduce the compensation that plaintiff otherwise would have been entitled to receive from defendant if you find that defendant's negligence was a legal cause of plaintiff's harm.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The phrase \"comparative fault\" means that the jury can divide the blame for an accident and that a person can be partly at fault but still be entitled to recover damages. A person is \"at fault\" if that person acted in such a way that a reasonably careful person would not have acted under the same or similar circumstances. Fault may include acts of carelessness, mistakes, errors of judgment, or failure to exercise reasonable care. If the person injured in an accident is partly at fault, the injured person is still entitled to recover if the other party was more at fault than the injured person. However, the amount of money the injured person receives must be reduced by the percentage of fault attributed to the injured person. You will be instructed further on this point.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is the principle of Duty to Mitigate Damages for Past Lost Earnings?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If the defendant disputes the amount of lost wages, the burden is on you to prove that the amount is reasonable. You must do your best to lessen those losses. This means that you must try to find another job, even if the new job pays less or is different from the job you had before. If you don't do your best to lessen your damages, the defendant can argue that you have failed to \"mitigate\" your damages.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When there is a breach of contract, damages to compensate for the breach are recoverable. Damages may be awarded for past losses and for losses likely to be suffered in the future. Courts require that any damages awarded must be reasonably foreseeable and capable of proof with reasonable certainty. Courts also require a damaged party to take reasonable efforts to lessen the damages. This is referred to as a duty to mitigate. Any contract damages are reduced by the net amount recovered from a substitute performance undertaken to mitigate damages.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If a court orders a party to pay damages for lost wages, the damages may be reduced based on a legal rule called the duty to mitigate damages. This rule requires the injured party to take reasonable steps to keep damages from increasing. For example, a worker who is injured on the job may have to look for similar work while waiting for a court case to be resolved. Otherwise the amount of damages is likely to be reduced to reflect the income the worker could have earned.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The principle of duty to mitigate damages states that a party injured by a breach of contract must take reasonable action under the circumstances to reduce the damages resulting from the breach. When it comes to damages in the form of lost earnings, a party may fulfill this duty by looking for alternative employment. When the party is able to find a job that is similar to the job lost due to the breach, the duty to mitigate is satisfied. However, even if a job is not similar, a party who takes lesser employment in good faith acts to mitigate damages.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"You may be wondering if you have a duty to mitigate damages. The short answer is yes. If you have been injured, you have a legal duty to mitigate damages. To do so, you should seek the medical treatment recommended by your doctor. The treatment should be appropriate for the type and extent of your injury. This medical treatment should include seeking the appropriate medical specialists and physical therapy, if necessary. You may also have a duty to mitigate damages with regard to lost wages or earning capacity. After an injury, you must try to return to your job or find a similar one, if you are able. If you can no longer do the type of work you were previously employed to do, you should seek training for another type of work consistent with your age, skills, and medical condition. If you don't seek this work or training, your settlement or judgment may be reduced if the insurance company or defendant believes you are failing to mitigate your damages. Click Here for more information from Legal Information Institute: Duty To Mitigate Damages","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The injured person is not entitled to damages for future lost earnings if he or she failed to take reasonable steps to reduce or avoid the loss or diminution of earnings. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you win a damage award in a personal injury claim, part of your award may be for earnings you are likely to lose in the future because of your injury.  On the other hand, after you recover from your injury, you have a duty or an obligation to make all reasonable efforts to reduce those foreseeable lost earnings. This is called the duty to mitigate damages. For example, if you were injured in an accident when you worked as a salesperson, you have a duty to make every reasonable effort after you recover to get your old job back or a comparable one at the same or similar salary. If you are successful, your recovery for lost earnings will be reduced by the salary you earn. If you did not make a reasonable effort to get your old job back or a comparable one, your damage award may be reduced even if you did not earn a salary. The same principle applies if you are awarded damages for future medical expenses.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If a court orders you to pay damages to compensate another person for lost earnings, it is because that person could prove the loss. It is not enough to show the amount of money actually lost; the person must also show that he or she took reasonable actions to reduce or eliminate the loss. For example, you cannot recover lost wages from an injury if you remained unemployed by choice. You must try to find a job within your ability to work.     Another example is attendance at school. If you can demonstrate that you took reasonable actions to reduce the loss, but it is unreasonable to expect you to eliminate the loss entirely, you are entitled to recover the loss.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If more than one year has passed since a personal injury was inflicted, you must prove the need to mitigate (limit) damages in order for the court to consider it. prompt: What is the legal standard for the Affirmative Defenseâ€”Employeeâ€™s Duty to Mitigate Damages?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The term \"mitigation (of damages)\" means to cause something (such as damage or pain) to become less severe. \"Mitigation\" is part of the duty of mitigation or obligation to mitigate damages. This duty requires a person who has suffered an injury to try to reduce or minimize the resulting harm. Generally the injured person cannot recover damages that could have been reasonably avoided. For an employee, this duty requires a person who has suffered an injury to try to find another job or otherwise lessen his or her damages, such as recovering lost wages or getting his or her benefits restored. For example, if a public employee is wrongfully terminated from his job, that employee has a duty to try to find another appropriate job until he is reinstated, if reinstatement is part of the remedy. The employee cannot recover a salary for the time that a reasonably appropriate job was open or refusal of a job offer. The duty to mitigate is not a right that can be waived.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"What must I prove if I serve as a defendant claiming employee's duty to mitigate damages? {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"In an action for breach of contract or for wrongful discharge of an employee, the injured party has a duty to \"mitigate damages,\" that is, to take steps that are reasonable under the circumstances to minimize the resulting damages. A discharged employee must make a good faith effort to obtain comparable employment or take reasonable steps to prevent an increase in damages. This does not necessarily mean that the employee must accept a substantial reduction in pay or otherwise accept terms of employment that are substantially different from those in the former employment. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If your mind were a car, your thoughts, feelings, and behaviors would be the driving forces, pushing and pulling you in different directions. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"How do we know that mental illnesses happen in the brain? Researchers have been searching for the causes of mental illness for nearly a hundred years. We used to think that mental illness was a reaction to difficulty in life. Indeed, anxiety and depression may be reasonable responses to losing a loved one, losing a job, being bullied, or having any number of other difficult events. However, for millions of Americans, anxiety, depression, and other mental disorders are serious illnesses that cause more than sadness or temporary worry. They are characterized by feelings of terror, despair, and hopelessness that do not go away and make it difficult for the person to function in daily life. These individuals need treatment from a mental health professional.    Today, we know that certain kinds of mental illness are linked to specific abnormal messages between nerve cells, or neurons, in the brain. We also know that many mental illnesses run in families, so the things we inherit from our parents must have some effect. Research shows that mental disorders can result from a number of causes including genetic factors; certain events in early life such as infections, diet, stress or exposure to toxins that affect brain development; and changes that occur later in life.    Brain changes associated with mental disorders may be chemical, structural, or both. It remains unclear if these brain changes are the cause or the effect of mental disorders. However, in most cases, treating the brain changes linked to the mental disorder corrects the mental illness as well.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"There are several things to remember about mental disorders, and how these disorders are diagnosed and treated.    Mental disorders are serious problems    People with these disorders are more than just \"a little sad\" or \"stressed out.\" Often, they have severe symptoms that affect their ability to work, study, socialize, and enjoy life. Almost half of all Americans will develop a mental disorder during their lifetime. More than 20 million have a disorder in any given year. Some disorders first appear in childhood - like ADHD and autism spectrum disorders. Others can strike at any time - like schizophrenia, depression, and anxiety disorders.     People are more than their diseases    People with mental disorders can learn to manage their illness, get back into their communities, and lead full, enjoyable lives.    Mental disorders, like many illnesses, may not have a single cause.    Scientists are learning that genes, stress, environment, and how you grew up, may all play a role. They also know that people without these disorders can have some of the same symptoms. Just because you feel sad or worried does not mean you have a mental disorder.     Treatment works    People get better. NIH research shows that treating mental disorders, early and properly, can help most people lead longer, healthier lives. Treatments often include medicines and/or talk therapy.     NIH: National Institute of Mental Health","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Key Elements of Mental Disorders\n                  Some of the key elements of any mental disorder include the following:       -  Distress - A person may feel upset or uncomfortable.    -  Disability - Impairment in one or more important areas of functioning, such as work, school, or personal relationships.  - Risk of Pain, Loss of Freedom, or Death - For example, people with a severe eating disorder risk death from starvation. People with severe mental illnesses like schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and major depression also die prematurely, on average 10 to 20 years earlier, than people in the general population. Early death is usually the result of an unhealthy lifestyle, compounded by side effects of medication. Cardiovascular disease, respiratory illness and infectious diseases are the most widely shared causes of death in these individuals. The risk of death from suicide is also high in this population.     -  Disorder - They reflect a breakdown in the brain's ability to keep certain aspects of thinking, feeling, or behavior \"normal.\"     -  Some disorders may be the direct effect of a specific disease of the brain, such as Parkinson's disease.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is the principle of Gravely Disabled Minor Explained?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"A gravely disabled minor is a child under 18 years old who, as a result of a mental illness:         -  Needs care, custody and control to avoid serious harm; and    - Lack of such care, custody and control.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Some parents or guardians may be concerned that their troubled child's needs will be overlooked because they are a minor and therefore can not demand treatment. In situations involving severely depressed or disturbed minors, caregivers may worry that the child will reject treatment and they will be powerless to help. Because of these concerns, state law lets parents and guardians seek court ordered evaluation and treatment for a gravely disabled minor child.    When a child with serious emotional disturbances refuses or does not understand his need for treatment, he will often resist treatment efforts. Such a child may also be unwilling or unable to express his wishes about treatment to a doctor. At times, these children need treatment that they are not competent to consent to, but which will help them. In such cases, a court lets parents and guardians seek treatment for their gravely disabled children.     A child is gravely disabled when, as a result of a mental illness, he is unable to provide for his/her basic needs such as food, clothing or shelter. United States Department of Health and Human Services, Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The principle of gravely disabled minor allows a physician to hospitalize a minor child who is in imminent danger of serious harm due to an inability to provide for their essential physical needs such as food, clothing or shelter or to care for themselves. Parents must be notified of the admission.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The purpose of the gravely disabled minor law is to enable parents to hospitalize, against the minor's will, a child who is a danger to himself or herself. In order to benefit from the law, the child must be between the ages of twelve and seventeen, and mentally ill. The mental illness must cause the child to be gravely disabled, meaning that the child is unable to provide for his or her basic needs, such as health, safety, and food, clothing, or shelter. Parents are required to notify the child's physician regarding their intent to invoke the gravely disabled minor law before the child is detained in court-ordered inpatient mental health treatment. Parents cannot be prevented from invoking the law.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is the principle of Obligation to Proveâ€”Reasonable Doubt?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"In a criminal case, the prosecutor must prove each element of the crime beyond a reasonable doubt. This means that the evidence is so strong that there is no reasonable doubt about the defendant's guilt. It does not require proof beyond all possible doubt. It is not the same as proof beyond a shadow of a doubt. It is not proof that eliminates every possible alternative explanation. A reasonable doubt is a doubt based on reason and common sense.     In a criminal trial, the defendant is presumed to be innocent, and no one has to prove that he or she is innocent. The prosecutor must prove that the defendant is guilty.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If the government brings a criminal complaint against you, you are presumed innocent unless and until a Jury or the judge in a bench trial finds that they are convinced beyond a reasonable doubt that you committed the crime.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"In a criminal case, the accused is presumed innocent until the prosecutor proves him guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. This is sometimes referred to as the \"gold standard\" of proof. To say something must be proved beyond a reasonable doubt means that the evidence must be so convincing that no reasonable person could question the accused's guilt. Reasonable doubt is a doubt based on reason and common sense. It is not a fanciful, speculative or forced doubt. A reasonable doubt is one that an impartial, rational person has after carefully weighing all the evidence.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"This pertains to how certain Core Democratic Values ( Accountability and Equality under the Law) relate to legal proceedings. Because the accused is assumed to be innocent until proven guilty, in criminal cases the prosecutor must prove the defendant is guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. In civil cases there are different types of proof.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Obligation to prove is the condition that rests upon the party who intends to prove a particular issue that such party must affirmatively convince the trier of fact. It makes the party compelled to justify his contention by a preponderance of the evidence. In a criminal case, the obligation is upon the government. In a civil case, it is upon the party claiming relief. Reasonable doubt is a doubt based upon reason and common sense after careful and impartial consideration of all the evidence. A reasonable doubt is not mere possible doubt; it is not a doubt raised by the imagination. It may arise from the lack of evidence. If, after such consideration, you are firmly convinced of the truth of the charge, you have no reasonable doubt. If, on the other hand, you think there is a real possibility that the charge is not true, you have reasonable doubt. When the charge is a criminal one, the law says that you should not convict the defendant if you have a reasonable doubt as to his guilt. The burden of proof is on the prosecution to convince you of the defendant's guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What are the elements of the Third Party Assistance?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If the Employment Agreement requires that the other Parties obtain third party approval, the the Parties need to delineate the elements related to that approval.  The Parties must first specify who the third parties are. Third party approval would typically be requested and/or obtained from a superior or entity who has oversight over the Parties and therefore has an interest in the terms of the Employment Agreement. For example, in an Employment Agreement where the Employer is a corporation, the Board of Directors would most likely be the third party from which approval would be sought.  The Parties also need to describe the process of seeking approval. If the process is not delineated, the approving party would not know how to grant approval. By way of example, if approval is to be sought from a Board of Directors, the Parties would need to specify whether a vote on the matter would be taken at a regular Board meeting or at a special meeting called for that purpose and how much approval/votes are needed to approve the Employment Agreement. The Parties might also spell out any necessary documentation needed in order to verify that approval was granted. In the above example, the Parties might require the minutes of the Board meeting at which the approval vote took place and a copy of the executed Employment Agreement with the approval vote clearly notated on it.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The elements of third-party assistance are patiently and steadily waiting, studying everything and everyone, setting a good example, and speaking personally.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"There are several elements of third party assistance:       - Levels: 3 levels are possible -- Mediation, Conciliation, and Arbitration.     - Power: 2 kinds of power may be used to achieve a solution -- Persuasion and Coercion.     - Tactics: The process of persuasion or coercion may involve many different kinds of tactics that a mediator, conciliator, or arbitrator could use.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The underlying principle of the Department's regulations on physical restraint is that the use of restraint should be avoided to the extent possible. Restraint should never be used as a form of punishment or discipline, for the convenience of staff, or as a substitute for appropriate supervision. Restraint can be used only when the student's behavior poses a threat of imminent, serious physical harm to the student or others. Restraint is prohibited if it interferes with a student's ability to communicate or breathe or if it restricts blood circulation. It is also prohibited unless administered by staff persons who are appropriately trained to ensure the student's safety. They allege that on at least one occasion within the past twelve months, the defendant has demonstrated a condition of grave disability.    The fact that the defendant has in the past been found to have a condition of grave disability, or has in the past been committed as a mentally disordered offender or to a hospital as a person who may be gravely disabled, is relevant to your determination whether at this time the defendant is gravely disabled.    If you find that the condition of grave disability has existed at other times in the past, it may support an inference that the defendant has the condition now. prompt: What is the jury instruction for Concluding Instruction?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Concluding Instruction. This concludes the instructions which the court will give you. The case is now ready for your decision. There are no specific legal rules for how to conduct your deliberations. You should consider all the evidence in the case carefully and discuss it fully with your fellow jurors. While you may talk about the case whenever you are together, you should not take the verdict form to the jury room until you begin your deliberations. You should not let anyone's opinion come before your own; and no one's opinion, including mine, is binding upon you. If during your deliberations you become aware of any dispute about the meaning of any part of these instructions, your foreperson should write me a note. I will come back to the courtroom and answer your question. Do not tell me how you stand on the issues. I will advise you if you are deadlocked or if it appears that you are reaching a verdict. prompt: What is the principle of fiduciary Duty Explained?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Fiduciary duty is the highest standard of care in equity or law. A fiduciary is expected to be extremely loyal to the person to whom he owes the duty. Avoiding conflicts of interest is also part of the fiduciary duty. Essentially, it is a recognition that one party may sometimes have to trust another to look out for his interests, even if it's against the other's interests.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Fiduciary duty is the highest standard of care at either equity or law. A fiduciary is expected to be extremely loyal to the person to whom he owes the duty: he must not put his personal interests before the duty, and he must not profit from his position as a fiduciary, unless the principal consents. A fiduciary must avoid conflicts of interest between himself and the one to whom he owes the duty. If a conflict of interest arises, it must be resolved in favor of the person to whom the duty is owed, or that person must give informed consent to it. Truefiduciary.com","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Fiduciary duties are the highest standard of care in either equity or law.\tA fiduciary duty is a legal or ethical relationship between two or more parties. Typically, it is a trust relationship between a trustee and a beneficiary. Because they are based on trust, when a fiduciary duty is breached, it harms that trust. Fiduciaries usually are entrusted with the care of money and property. The parties to a fiduciary relationship can agree on certain responsibilities and ways to enforce them. Courts can, however, impose certain duties on the parties regardless of any agreement to the contrary.    Important types of fiduciary duties are       -  The duty of a lawyer to act in the best interests of his or her client    -  The duty of a guardian to attend to the needs of the ward    -  The duty of one in charge of a property to act in that owner's best interests        You can be held liable for breaches of fiduciary duty if a person suffers harm because of your relationship with another. To decide if you have a valid claim against someone who breached a fiduciary duty, courts look at whether there was a fiduciary relationship and whether it was breached.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Principle of fiduciary duty states that a fiduciary must act in the best interests of the beneficiary and must not put his personal interests before that of the beneficiary. A fiduciary must discharge his duties with loyalty and care. An example is a trustee. The trustee must put the interests of the beneficiaries first and not use the trust property for his or her own benefit.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Fiduciary duty is the highest standard of care. It is a legal obligation of one party to act in the best interest of another. The obligated party is typically entrusted with property, information or power to carry out its mandate. The party owing the duty is called the fiduciary, and the one to whom the duty is owed is called the principal or the beneficiary. Examples of fiduciary relationships include those between a trustee and a beneficiary; a board member and a corporation that the board member serves; a lawyer and client; or a guardian and ward. Conflict of interests and self-dealing are typically prohibited in these relationships.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Part of what makes a relationship fiduciary is that the person in the relationship gives away (delegates) power over a particular issue. This power delegation is in a form of trust, and the other person (the plaintiff in a lawsuit) is a beneficiary of that trust relationship.    A leading case that describes a fiduciary relationship is the case Meinhard v. Salmon, 164 N.E. 545 (N.Y. 1928). The two parties to the case were in a joint venture where one party was a managing party and one party was a sleeping partner. When the managing party learned of an opportunity to develop a hotel operation on jointly owned land and pursued that opportunity without the effective knowledge or consent of the sleeping partner, the sleeping partner sued. The court held that a fiduciary relationship does exist, quoting from Wheaton v. Wheaton, 4 Paige 32:       \"(The parties stood) in such a relation to each other, that the one must not, without the other's express consent, adopt any measure respecting the thing which is the subject of the confidence, or act in any manner concerning it, otherwise than for the other's benefit ...\"    That is why the duty of loyalty is one of the most important parts of a fiduciary relationship. To succeed in suing for a breach of fiduciary duty, however, you have to prove that you have a fiduciary relationship with the person you are suing.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If the director violates the fiduciary duty, such a violation entitles the victim to seek judicial remedies. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Essential factual elements - Under the law, an employee owes a duty of undivided loyalty to his employer. The term \"undivided loyalty\" means that an employee should not put himself or herself in a position in which his or her loyalty to the employer can be affected or influenced by self-interest or by the interest of one or more persons hostile to the employer. An employee acting adversely or hostile to his or her employer breaches this duty.  An employee who goes behind his or her employer's back with the hopes of eventually displacing the employer or otherwise acquiring the employer's business acts adversely to the employer.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"An agent has a duty of undivided loyalty to the principal. This duty requires that the agent act so as to advance the interests of the principal only and not to obtain personal gains and benefits for himself or herself or to advance the interests of a third party. Generally, an agent act in a fiduciary relationship with a principal. This means that the agent must exercise the utmost good faith and loyalty to the principal and is not permitted to gain any secret profit or advantage because of such relationship.  An agent who receives any money or profit in excess of that specified in the agency agreement or as compensation for services must account for all such money and profits to the principal. A breach of the duty of loyalty includes when the agent acts on his or her own behalf, purchases property without disclosing the agency, deals as an adversary against the principal, or competes with the principal. If the agent breaches his or her duty of undivided loyalty to the principal, the principal has the right to recover against the agent all damages resulting from the breach.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is the principle of Duties of Escrow Holder?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"During a real estate transaction, a neutral third party often handles transfer of documents, money, or both. This person or company is called an escrow holder. The escrow holder could be an escrow company, title company, or the real estate broker. The escrow holder is frequently used in buying a home because of the large sums of money involved and the need for both the buyer and the seller to meet certain conditions before the transaction is completed.    For example, the escrow holder may be instructed to transfer the deed to the buyer only after the seller receives the down payment and loan approval. The escrow holder complies with the instructions of the parties and cannot take sides.    Michigan Department of Insurance and Financial Services","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"An escrow holder is not a party to the escrow agreement and has no interest in it other than the compensation agreed upon for the performance of its duties. It is not liable for the acts of the parties. The escrow holder is required to remain neutral. He has no authority except for the duties and obligations set forth in the agreement. Duties may be ministerial or discretionary. A ministerial duty is one to be performed in a prescribed manner without the exercise of judgment. Discretionary duties may be performed in various ways where one or more courses are open to the escrow holder. The escrow holder has the duties of (1) care, (2) impartiality, (3) to notify, (4) to keep separate, and (5) to account. In performing its duties, the escrow holder must act as a fiduciary, an agent or a trustee, depending upon the relationship with the parties.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Escrow holders have certain duties. They must:       - Act in good faith     - Follow the agreement they have with the parties    - Not unreasonably refuse to deliver or disburse money or documents in their possession    - Keep proper records of their transactions, and     - Keep the money and the property in their possession separate.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Escrow is the process whereby an innocent third person or corporation has custody of money or documents on behalf of two other persons until the instructions of the parties are carried out. The duties of the escrow holder should be agreed upon in writing. As part of these duties, the holder may not take instructions from only one party. It is the duty of the escrow holder to see that the conditions of the escrow are carried out to the satisfaction of both parties.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"28 Am. Jur. 2d Escrows § 16 provides a nice overview on the Duties of an Escrow Holder: An escrow holder has a duty to follow the terms of the escrow agreement and generally does not have discretion to refuse a tender which the escrow agreement requires it to accept. It is not bound to act as the agent of one party to the exclusion of the other, and cannot therefore lawfully pay out the escrow to one party, when the other has offered to perform the acts on which payment is to be conditional. An escrow is regarded as a fund or res which the escrowee is to hold for the mutual benefit of the parties to the escrow. Accordingly, an escrow holder may refuse to deliver the escrow property unless the parties authorize the delivery or its terms so provide. If neither party is entitled to the property, the escrow may still be held, and the escrow holder may be held liable if he releases it to a party who is not entitled thereto. A party who has received property from the escrow holder under a mistaken interpretation of his rights under an escrow agreement must restore it to the escrow if it has not been delivered and a different disposition of the property is thus not prevented. If the receipt thereof has prevented a further delivery, the other party may not recover compensation from that party for the amount of the property. One who receives property from an escrow to which he is not then entitled to is estopped to deny that he has received it. Unless otherwise agreed, an escrow holder is entitled to reasonable compensation for his services, and he has a lien for such compensation upon the property held in escrow.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

This is because a speculative investor is one who consciously accepts a higher degree of risk than an average investor. Speculative investments have a higher degree of risk, a lower degree of liquidity, and/or a less certain prospect of income than non-speculative investments.  Speculative securities generally are not suitable for a conservative individual who can afford to lose only a small part of his or her investment portfolio. However, speculative securities may be suitable in limited amounts for an individual with assets sufficient to maintain a conservative level of investments to meet financial goals and who has sufficient income and networth to withstand a substantial loss of the speculative investment.  While all of the decisions an investor makes can affect how likely it is that the investor will be able to reach his or her investment goals, in some circumstances it is more important to be concerned about specific types of investment risks. In order to establish a cause of action for breach of fiduciary duty against an attorney, a plaintiff must prove: 1. That the attorney owed a duty to the plaintiff; 2. That the attorney breached that duty; 3. That the attorney's breach was the legal cause of some injury; and 4. That the plaintiff suffered some injury that is recoverable at law or in equity. In addition, to prevail on a breach of fiduciary duty claim against his or her attorney, the plaintiff must show that the attorney acted fraudulently, in bad faith, or egregiously. (Gorman v. Moran, 127 Cal. 544, 59 P. 1052.) A client is entitled to have his interests preserved to him by an unselfish devotion of his counsel's best skill and care, and there is a breach of the counsel's obligations in law whenever his interest in a transaction with the client is such as to permit him to make advantage to himself to the damage or detriment of the client. prompt: How is Duty of Disclosure by Real Estate Broker to Client explained to the jury?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The phrase \"duty of disclosure\" means that a real estate broker is responsible for giving their client all important information about the transaction. The duty of disclosure is part of the broker's \"fiduciary duties\". The fiduciary duties are the duties of undivided loyalty, obedience, disclosure, confidentiality, and reasonable care.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The fact that you hired a real estate broker to help you in a real estate transaction creates a principal-agent relationship between you and the broker. Agency law applies to all principal-agent relationships unless there is a statute that states otherwise. This means the following laws apply to the relationship you have with the broker. Every broker has a duty of disclosure to his or her client. This means that if the broker has information that is important to you, that the broker believes you should know, or thinks you would want to know, the broker        -  must share the information with you and    -  should not tell other people but not you        The broker's duty of disclosure also applies to negotiations with third parties. This means that if the broker is negotiating on your behalf with another person, and the broker gets an offer or finds out information that is important to you, the broker must promptly tell you.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The real estate broker-client contract between you and your real estate broker requires your broker to use reasonable skill and care when performing the duties that you and your broker have agreed upon. If you and your broker have agreed that your broker will find a suitable home for you, then your broker must use reasonable skill and care to perform that task.    When you and your real estate broker make your written real estate broker-client contract, you tell your broker what type of property you want. There are many different types of property. Examples are single-family homes, cooperative apartments, condominiums, agricultural land, commercial property, and industrial property. You also tell your broker the geographical area where you want the property to be. Your broker then has a duty to look for property of the general type and in the general area that you told your broker you wanted.    A real estate broker is not required to find properties that you might want to buy to drive past and look at, even if you later decide you would like to buy the property. Your real estate broker is not responsible for performing other activities that have not been agreed upon between you and your real estate broker, including making sure that you have sufficient funds for the down payment or for financing of a property, or assisting you in arranging financing.    A real estate broker has your permission to disclose information to third parties that is not material to the transaction. If you want your broker to keep something a secret, you must tell your broker.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}
