{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Duty of Disclosure by Real Estate Broker to Client is explained to the jury as follows: The real estate brokerage contracts to perform various real estate business services on behalf of the client to whom the broker is rendering the representation, such as a prospective purchaser or seller. The services may include listing a property for sale; marketing, showing and carrying out the purchase of a property; renting or leasing a property; and carrying out the purchase or sale of a property. When carrying out these services, the real estate broker owes a duty to the client. As one element of a client's cause of action against a real estate broker for breach of this duty, the client must prove that there was a breach of the duty. In this regard, a real estate broker has a duty of disclosure to his or her client. A real estate broker must disclose to his or her client all material information that is known to the broker or that the broker should have know.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is the principle of Constructive Fraud (Civ. Code, Â§ 1573)?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Constructive fraud is a breach of duty which, regardless of human intent, the law declares to be fraudulent because of its tendency to deceive others or violate their confidence. The facts or circumstances of the particular case determine whether a breach of duty is constructive fraud.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Constructive fraud consists of any act, omission, or concealment involving a breach of duty, trust or confidence which does not necessarily proceed from an intent to deceive, but which is regarded as highly culpable because of its tendency to deceive others and to violate confidence.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Constructive fraud is a breach of a legal or equitable duty which, irrespective of the moral guilt of the person who owes the duty, is declared by law to be a fraud. In the typical form of constructive fraud, one party is bound to make full disclosure to another, and the failure to do so, coupled with a resulting injury to the latter, constitutes constructive fraud.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Constructive fraud is a breach of duty which, regardless of [GC] intent, gains an advantage to the person at fault or anyone claiming under that person by misleading another to his prejudice.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Constructive Fraud arises from a breach of duty that the law declares fraudulent because it tends to deceive others, to violate their confidence or to inflict injury on their interests. It includes a breach of fiduciary duty and a fiduciary's concealment of material facts with an intent to deceive. Constructive fraud is often based on an unfair advantage and does not necessarily require a showing of intent to defraud. Therefore, actual fraud is not necessary. However, constructive fraud may exist even if the party charged with the fraud sincerely believed that he was acting properly.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What are the elements of the Affirmative Defenseâ€”Statute of Limitations?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The elements of the affirmative defense of statute of limitations are: The legislature has prescribed a limited period during which a person may bring suit; That period has expired; and The defendant asserts the defense, usually by a motion to dismiss.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"To defend yourself using the statute of limitations, you have the burden of proving that the limitation period has passed. Once you have proved this the plaintiff could be unable to continue the case unless he or she can show something that might toll, or extend, the statute. Tolling of a statute can occur for several reasons:       -  The plaintiff was a minor when the cause of action accrued    - The plaintiff was legally insane when the cause of action accrued    - The defendant has committed a fraudulent act to prevent the plaintiff from filing on time    -  The defendant committed some part of the wrongful act after the expiration of the statute           You might need additional forms to claim these exceptions to the statute.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Because of the passage of time the Statute of Limitations operates to bar the plaintiff's claim.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The statute of limitations is an affirmative defense. In order to successfully assert the defense, the defendant must show that the amount of time allowed for bringing the lawsuit has expired. The amount of time allowed is set by state law, and varies based on the type of claim.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The statute of limitations is an affirmative defense in a lawsuit. If the statute of limitations expires, the lawsuit will usually be dismissed.  Every state and the federal government have their own statutes of limitation. These statutes are usually different for different types of lawsuits. For example, a personal injury lawsuit may have a limitation of 2 years, a breach of contract lawsuit 6 years, and a medical malpractice claim 3 years. The limitation period usually begins to run from either the time the claim accrued or the time the plaintiff discovered or should have discovered the injury, harm, or breach giving rise to the claim (or reasonably should have discovered it). If a plaintiff waits until the statute of limitations has run to bring a claim, the defendant can bring an affirmative defense asserting the running of the statute of limitations, which, if established, will bar the claim.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"You must decide whether \"actual intent to hinder, delay, or defraud a creditor\" existed. As with any actual intent, this is established if you find that the party intended the natural consequences of his or her actions. It does not require proof that the party specifically intended to violate the law. Actual intent may be inferred from the circumstances. Evidence that the party was insolvent or became insolvent as a result of the action, or was indebted or became indebted as a result of the action, is some evidence of actual intent .","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Actual intent to hinder, delay or defraud a creditor means that the debtor made a transfer or incurred an obligation for the purpose of preventing a creditor from collecting what it is owed.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The plaintiff in a fraudulent transfer action has the burden of proving, by clear and convincing evidence, that the transfer was made with \"actual intent to hinder, delay, or defraud\" a creditor. There is no exact formula for determining whether a transfer was motivated by \"actual intent.\" However, under part (a)(1) of section 3439.04 of the Civil Code, a jury may consider any one or more of the following \"badges of fraud\" to determine whether the transfer was made with the required intent:        - whether the transferor was insolvent or became insolvent shortly after the transfer was made;    - whether the transferor was engaged in or about to enter a business or a transaction for which the remaining assets of the transferor were unreasonably small; or    - whether the transferor intended to incur debts beyond its ability to pay as they become due.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

Under that prong, a transfer is \\\"constructively fraudulent\\\" if:        - The debtor did not receive a reasonably equivalent value in exchange for the transfer or obligation; and    - The debtor was either       - Insolvent at that time or became insolvent as a result of the transfer or obligation; or       - Engaged in a business or a transaction, or was about to engage in a business or a transaction, for which the remaining assets were unreasonably small in relation to the business or transaction; or       - Intended to incur, or believed or reasonably should have believed that he or she would incur, debts beyond the debtor's ability to pay as they became due.        The fraudulent transfer laws impose liability on debtors, transferees, and others who receive property and benefit from a fraudulent transfer.     Detailed Information. Section 3439.04(a)(2) of the Civil Code sets forth one element of the constructive fraud prong of a fraudulent transfer claim. Under that prong, a transfer is considered \\\"constructively fraudulent\\\" if:        - The debtor did not receive a reasonably equivalent value in exchange for the transfer or obligation; and    - The debtor was either       - Insolvent at that time or became insolvent as a result of the transfer or obligation; or       - Engaged in a business or a transaction, or was about to engage in a business or a transaction, for which the remaining assets were unreasonably small in relation to the business or transaction; or       - Intended to incur, or believed or reasonably should have believed that he or she would incur, debts beyond the debtor's ability to pay as they became due.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"How can businesses tell if they are in trouble? The presumption of insolvency looks at common signs of potential financial distress for a business or corporation. Some of these signs include       - Making only minimum payments for an extended period of time on obligations such as payroll taxes, sales taxes, withholding taxes, and other taxes;     - Having debt in relation to income where the business or corporation is on the \"downward slope\" of the \"income/debt curve\" (see graph below);     - Making payments under an installment agreement with the IRS;     - Filing for bankruptcy or having bad debts;     - Obtaining loans from relatives, friends, or business associates;     - Frequently closing and reopening businesses using the same or similar names; and     - Selling off business assets or taking on new debt.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The presumption of insolvency consists of three elements: a careful balancing of rights, duties, and interests that protects the non-dishonest debtor's ability to start over while discouraging and redressing abuse; a finding of insolvency itself; and the timeframe of insolvency.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The presumption of insolvency is set forth in the Bankruptcy Code section 303(h)(1). The presumption of insolvency arises and applies when the petitioning creditors hold more than a majority in number and at least two-thirds in dollar amount of the claims of the creditors not the debtor, the debtor's relatives or an insured depository institution. 11 U.S.C. 303(h)(1).","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The elements of the presumption of insolvency are listed in URAA 32A, Schedule 3, Sch 1, item 5 and Schedule 2, Sch 1, item 5, respectively, and are as follows:     (a) the person owes a debt or other liability to a creditor; and    (b) has committed an act of insolvency within 6 months of the failure to pay the debt when it became due and payable; and    (c) the person is insolvent at the time that the debt becomes due and payable or becomes insolvent within 6 months after that time; and    (d) the debt has not been paid within 3 business days after the day on which the debt became due and payable.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"A \"fixed-term tenancy\" may be created orally or by a written lease for a specific amount of time. For example, \"I will rent my apartment to you for six months, at a cost of $500 each month.\" There is no longer a need for an actual lease document for fixed-term tenancies, however a written lease is encouraged. A \"tenancy\" is an agreement under which a party agrees to rent property owned by another. A tenancy can also be called a \"lease.\" Under the Leases chapter of the Code of Civil Procedure, a fixed-term tenancy expires automatically on the termination date stated in the agreement. When a fixed-term tenancy ends, the tenant has the duty to surrender the property to the landlord. prompt: What does Termination for Failure to Pay Rentâ€”Essential Factual Elements require under the law?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Under the law, in order to evict a tenant for not paying rent, the landlord must comply with the essential factual elements of the claim. This means that the landlord must prove the following: the parties entered into a rental agreement (usually a written agreement) the tenant owes rent under the agreement and that there is a specific amount owed the tenant owes the rent that is due, there was no receipt tender of the rent; and the current landlord was entitled to the possession of the premises when the rental agreement was entered into and is entitled to possess the premises at the time the eviction actions initiated.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The essential elements of the cause of action for nonpayment in Texas are:        - a landlord/Tenant relationship;     - an unexpired lease term;     - an obligation under the lease of the tenant to pay rent;    - the tenant's failure to pay rent when due; and    - a demand for payment of the rent.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When a landlord wants to evict a tenant because he or she failed to pay rent, the landlord must file a court case called an \"unlawful detainer\" action. As the defendant, the tenant's answer to the complaint must admit or deny each of the factual allegations made by the landlord.  The essential factual elements of the landlord's action must include the following:        - An agreement was made between the parties to pay a specified amount for rent;    - The date or dates the rent was to be paid;    - The fact that the agreed-upon rent has not been paid; and    - That the landlord has complied with all of his or her other obligations under the lease. (If a lease is not involved, the landlord must allege facts that show he or she has complied with a purported rental agreement.)","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"A landlord who has been given a court order to take back possession of the apartment cannot knock on your door one day and evict you. The landlord must ask the sheriff to evict you. You have the right to be present when the sheriff arrives. If you are there, the sheriff must wait 15 minutes before making you leave. You may ask a friend, a social worker, a housing advocate, or another official to be there with you.    If you do not have the rent, you cannot prevent the eviction simply by asking for more time or refusing to pay. The landlord must have a valid Sheriff Eviction Order. You cannot stop the eviction by offering to pay on the spot.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"In a suit for eviction based on nonpayment of rent, the landlord has the burden of proving the essential factual elements of the case. prompt: What does Termination for Violation of Terms of Lease/Agreementâ€”Essential Factual Elements require under the law?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When the landlord asks the court to evict a tenant, the landlord must prove that the tenant violated the Terms of the Lease. Examples of violations can include nonpayment of rent and other breaches of the lease or rental agreement. In some situations, if the violation involves a breach other than nonpayment of rent, the landlord must show that he/she gave the tenant thirty (30) days' written notice and an opportunity to correct the violation before filing for eviction.     Unless the tenant has raised a defense, the landlord should get a judgement for possession of the premises once the landlord has established all of the essential elements of his/her case.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Most landlords require a lease or rental agreement. This is a contract that lists all of the obligations you are required to meet. It also lists the rules of your tenancy. Typical rules require that you maintain the rental unit; that you don't disturb neighbors; and that you do not use the unit for illegal purposes, like selling drugs.     When a lease or rental agreement is for a specific length of time, such as one year, the landlord usually cannot end the tenancy until the term is over. When the tenant fails to follow the terms of the lease during that year, most landlords can ask the tenant to move out at the end of the year. Some states also allow landlords to end the tenancy early. They may first have to send the tenant a notice to correct the violation or move. If the tenant does not comply, the landlord begins an eviction lawsuit.    If your tenancy is at-will or month-to-month, the landlord can terminate the tenancy for violation of the lease, but must provide a notice to terminate and a reasonable opportunity to move out of the premises.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Under Washington law, a landlord may try to evict a tenant for violating a condition of the lease. This could be any provision in the lease like :     - Not having a pet;    - Not having more people than the lease allows; or    - Not doing anything that disturbs other tenants.       With few exceptions, a violation of any of the terms of the rental agreement is grounds for eviction. However, the lease itself can provide the landlord with the right to evict only after certain steps have been taken. For example, a lease may provide the landlord has the right to evict only after issuing one or more warning notices to the tenant regarding the violation.   When a landlord files an eviction lawsuit against you for violation of lease, the landlord must admit, deny or claim no knowledge of the allegations of the complaint within a specific time period. This is called an Answer. In the Answer, you may also raise a counterclaim. A counterclaim is a claim you have against the landlord.    In some cases, having a defense and/or counterclaim may delay the eviction. The procedures can be complicated, so it is important to consult a lawyer or find legal assistance if you want help.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When an apartment owner or manager agrees to rent an apartment to a tenant, they sign a lease/agreement. The lease gives the tenant certain rights, such as the right to the quiet enjoyment of the premises. The lease also gives the tenant obligations, such as the obligation to pay rent and not disturb the neighbors. It also requires the tenant to refrain from running a business from the apartment. If the tenant violates a provision of the lease/agreement, the apartment owner can terminate the lease/agreement and evict the tenant.  When the apartment owner serves the tenant with a lawsuit, the apartment owner has to show the court the essential factual elements which prove that the tenant violated the lease/agreement. These factual elements are the specifics of what provisions of the lease/agreement the tenant violated.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The law requires that a landlord give the following information about the lease violation to the tenant in a \"notice to correct or quit\" or in the \"notice to quit.\"    - The dates of the lease violation that the landlord alleges in the complaint.    - The nature of the lease violation that the landlord alleges in the complaint.    - The provisions of the lease that are contradicted by the alleged violation.       The law also requires that if the lease violation is that the tenant owes rent, the landlord include a statement explaining how the tenant can redeem the tenancy. For example, the statement might indicate that the tenant can redeem the tenancy by paying the landlord all the unpaid rent (and late fees, if the lease provides for them) within the time period allowed by the landlord. If the lease allows the tenant to pay in installments and the landlord will accept that arrangement, the statement should explain the payment schedule.     No particular form of notice is required. prompt: What does Termination of Month-to-Month Tenancyâ€”Essential Factual Elements require under the law?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The landlord or tenant must give a written notice to terminate month-to-month tenancy. The termination must specify the termination of the tenancy and the date on which the tenancy will terminate. The termination date must be at least:       - 21 days from the date of service of the notice if rent is due every week;    - 30 days from the date of service of the notice if rent is due every two weeks or every month; or    - 90 days from the date of service of the notice if the owner has received a notice to quit from a government agency.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you are a landlord or a tenant and want to end a month-to-month tenancy, there are specific requirements you need to follow under the law in California:       - The landlord or the tenant must notify the other of the termination of the tenancy.    - The notice must be written.    - The landlord must give the tenant a specified number of days to quit, i.e., to move out or give up possession of the property. The number of days depends on the reason for termination and sometimes on the age and disability of the tenant.     - The termination of tenancy is waived if the landlord ratifies or approves continued residence after the specified time to move out expires.       These requirements apply to all tenancies in which the landlord has the right to possession, and which do not have a fixed term. In other words, month-to-month tenancies are not the only tenancies to which these rules apply. The rules also apply if, for example, the tenancy is \"from week to week\" or if a fixed term of a year or longer expires and the parties continue the tenancy without another written agreement of a fixed term.    See also Tips for Tenants: Ending Your Tenancy and Tips for New Tenants, Checking Out.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"This statute requires that a termination of a month-to-month tenancy be in writing and signed by the party giving the notice or a person authorized to do so on that party's behalf. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"How soon must a landlord or tenant give notice to end an estate from month to month? If a landlord or tenant wants to end a tenancy that is from month-to-month, the landlord or tenant must give reasonable notice. There are no set rules on what period of time is reasonable.    If the tenancy has lasted for less than three months, the period of notice should not be longer than the length of tenancy. Therefore the minimum notice period would be one day.    If the tenancy has lasted three months or more, the period of notice should be no less than three days.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When you decide this case, you should apply the legal standard for sufficiency and service of notice of termination of a month-to-month tenancy. Under this legal standard, the landlord must give a written notice of termination of the tenancy (notice) to the tenant at least 30 days before the expiration of the rental period. The notice must be signed by the landlord or the landlord's authorized agent, designate the date on which the rental period will terminate, and state the reason for termination. The landlord must either deliver or mail the notice to the tenant. Delivery can be by handing it directly to the tenant or by leaving it with some person at the tenant's residence who is apparently at least 15 years old. Upon mailing, the notice will be effective to terminate the tenancy one day after the first rental period expires after mailing.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The jury in this case has three main issues to decide. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The case law regarding Necessity of Sufficient and Proper Service of Notice for the Termination of a Month- to-Month Tenancy is detailed below. A landlord may terminate a month-to-month tenancy by giving advance written notice to the tenant. Under Maryland Code, Real Property, Section 8-402, such written notice must be given at least one (1) month prior to the next rental payment due date. There are various ways in which the landlord may give such advance notice to the tenant, including certified mail and personal delivery. Each method must meet certain criteria, such as a personal delivery (where the landlord or landlord's agent must actually hand the written notice to the tenant). Maryland law further provides for the presumed receipt of such termination notice. Under the statute, a written notice mailed by certified mail shall be presumed to have been received by the addressee on the earlier to occur of (i) its actual receipt or (ii) the fifth day after the day on which it was mailed. Cases interpreting this statute have held that service, like any other element of a landlord's complaint, must be proven sufficient in a landlord's unlawful detainer action. If the landlord fails to prove that the tenant was properly served, the landlord cannot recover possession of the property because, without sufficient notice of the termination, the tenancy continues. See the summary regarding these cases below.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: How should a jury apply Affirmative Defenseâ€”Implied Warranty of Habitability?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"A landlord shall maintain a unit of residential property so that it meets the requirements of the applicable building, housing and health codes for the duration of the lease. The failure of a landlord to do so shall be an implied warranty. This means that all leases include this warranty, whether or not you read it or signed it. The failure of a landlord to make a repair resulting from landlord negligence shall also be an implied warranty. If you are a tenant and the landlord fails to make a necessary repair, you are not required to move out of the unit if it is unfit. Before moving out, you must give the landlord a reasonable time to make the repair and notify the landlord of your intention to move out if the repair is not made. Once notified, the landlord has a reasonable time to either make the repair or to offer a comparable repair or rental unit. If you stop paying rent because the condition of the dwelling decreases its rental value, you must keep the rent that is due in an escrow account until the dispute is resolved.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Every state has laws saying that landlords have to keep a rental unit habitable, or safe to live in. Landlords must keep and maintain the rental unit so that it meets all state and local building codes and health ―sanitary\" laws. It is against the law for landlords to rent units that violate these codes and laws. If the unit already violates these laws and codes, it is often within the tenant's rights not to move in.   Landlords are also usually responsible for fixing any problems that they cannot expect you (the tenant) to fix yourself. Later, if you have a problem that is the landlord's responsibility, you may be escrowing your rent, moving out, or keeping the rent money. These factors will affect whether withholding the rent is a good idea.   Things that are wrong with a rental unit that may make it uninhabitable may include unsafe electrical wiring, lack of heat, plumbing problems, no locks, mosquito infestation, or lack of running water. A problem that does not make the unit lively unsafe or unfit is missing carpeting.   U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development Office of Housing Counseling","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Jury Instructions: Failure of the Landlord to Maintain the Premises as Required by Law-Affirmative Defense-Implied Warranty of Habitability An implied warranty of habitability is the landlord's implied promise to keep a leased property fit for habitation. It does not require the landlord to make changes or repairs pursuant to local or state building or housing codes prior to the beginning of a lease. However, it does require that the landlord make repairs to bring the property into compliance with applicable building or housing codes unless (1) the tenant wholly or partially caused the noncompliance, or (2) the need for the repair stems from a condition not present at the time the tenant took possession, the tenant gave notice to the landlord regarding the condition in writing, and the landlord failed to make a reasonable effort to repair the condition within a reasonable time after receiving the tenant's written notice. The warrant of habitability lasts only for the period of the landlord/tenant relationship unless the parties agree otherwise.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"How does the implied warranty of habitability affect a landlord's defenses? If the landlord proves that the tenant has, without limitation:       - Destroyed property or committed waste on the premises;    - Used the premises for illegal purposes;    - Caused or allowed to exist a nuisance on the premises; or    - Violated a condition in the lease other than one relating to the habitability of the premises,    then the tenant's breach of the lease relieves the landlord of the landlord's obligation under the warranty with respect to the aspects of the premises that were destroyed. The landlord is not relieved, however, of the obligation with respect to the other aspects of the premises.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The tenant claims that the landlord violated the statute against \"retaliatory eviction.\" The tenant has the burden of proving each of the following:       1. That the tenant is or was a residential tenant; and    2. That the landlord evicted the tenant, made the tenancy subject to a condition that is not permitted by the rental agreement, ousted the tenant from the premises, or threatened to do any of those things; and    3. That either:             a. The tenant made a written complaint to the landlord, or to a government agency, that the landlord has violated a building or housing code or a law relating to health or safety, or that the landlord has violated the rental agreement; or      b.  The landlord did not give the tenant written payment or performance demands as required by law before attempting to recover possession of the rental unit; and              4. The eviction, ousting, or threat to do so was in retaliation for the tenant's actions described in paragraph 3 above, conducted without the good faith belief that the repayment or performance demanded had not been made or had not been made or tendered timely, or done after the landlord declared that the landlord will not accept the repayment or performance and the tenant has tendered the repayment or performance.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"You must first decide whether the landlord brought an eviction against the tenant. If you find for the landlord on all elements of its claim for eviction, you need not consider the tenant's affirmative defense. If the landlord brought an eviction against the tenant, you must decide whether the tenant proved the affirmative defense of retaliatory eviction by a preponderance of the evidence. A preponderance of the evidence means the greater weight of the evidence. In other words, to prove that it is more likely than not that the facts are as the party asserts.    A tenant may have the defense of retaliatory eviction if the landlord evicts the tenant within 180 days after the tenant has done one or more of the following:       Landlord has Misdemeanor Violations of the Health and Safety Code    The tenant in good faith complains that the landlord has violated a law or ordinance relating to the health or safety of tenants if the violation is a misdemeanor under the Health and Safety Code.    Landlord has Multiple Violations of the Building, Housing, and Health and Safety Codes    The tenant in good faith complains that the landlord has violated two or more laws or ordinances relating to the health, safety, and housing and safety standards of the landlord's dwellings or of similar dwellings in the local jurisdiction.    Tenant Organizer or Tenant Union Member    The tenant is an organizer or has been elected as a representative of a tenant union or tenant association.    Landlord Demands Money or Threatens Action for Exercise of a Right    The tenant has done acts which are the exercise of a legal right related to the premises, including the payment of rent to which the landlord is entitled, or exercising rights under the lease, or under an agreement with the landlord, such as agreeing to pay rent to the landlord or a representative of the landlord.    Other acts by the tenant which are a legal exercise of a right or an attempt to exercise a right. It is not a defense that the acts were a breach of a rental agreement or other agreement with the landlord, if the breach was not excused by the landlord.       You are instructed that the above list of acts by the tenant which may be a defense of retaliatory eviction is not exclusive. The statute specifically states that nothing shall be construed to limit the rights of the tenant or landlord under the laws of this state. This instruction is taken from the Judicial Council of California Civil Jury Instructions (CACI), number 3251.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"What are the elements of discriminatory eviction as an affirmative defense under the Unruh Act in California? The Unruh Act prohibits a business establishment from discriminating against a person based on certain specified characteristics. It applies to all business establishments, including landlords. If a landlord refuses to rent to a person, evicts a person, or treats a tenant unequally based on that person's protected characteristic, then the landlord has discriminated against that tenant or tenant-applicant. The elements of discriminatory eviction under the Unruh Act are: 1. The landlord was a business establishment; 2. The landlord refused to rent to a person, evicted a person, or treated a tenant unequally; and 3. The reason for the landlord's conduct was that the tenant or tenant-applicant was a member of a protected class.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"What are the elements of the affirmative defense - discriminatory eviction (Unruh Act)? The elements of discriminatory eviction under the Unruh Act are: that the plaintiff is protected under the Act; that the plaintiff was in a business establishment; and that the defendant refused to rent or lease to the plaintiff, or evicted or threatened to evict the plaintiff, because of the plaintiffs protected characteristic. The Act prohibits discrimination based on the traits listed in its text, and California courts have construed it extremely broadly, so as to prohibit virtually all forms of discrimination. The Unruh Act expressly applies to discrimination by \"all business establishments.\" Although the Unruh Act does not define \"business establishment,\" California courts have held that the phrase means any business entity that provides goods, services, facilities, privileges, or accommodations to the public, either directly or by invitation. This would therefore include rental apartments.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What does Affirmative Defenseâ€”Failure to Comply With Rent Control Ordinance/Tenant Protection Act require under the law?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"An \"affirmative defense\" is a set of facts or legal reasons that, if proven by the tenant, can limit or cancel the landlord's ability to evict the tenant.  The requirement that a landlord must obey the Rent Control Ordinance/Tenant Protection Act (which all landlords must do whether a tenant brings it up in an eviction case or not) is part of \"just cause\" - a valid reason to evict a tenant. If the landlord is evicting you for a reason that does not qualify as \"just cause,\" that means the landlord is using an \"unlawful reason\" (or no reason at all) to evict you. An unlawful reason is not a reason that the law allows.     One reason that is not a \"just cause\" is a landlord's failure to comply with the Rent Control Ordinance or the Tenant Protection Act. This means the landlord and/or landlord's agents failed to obey some part or parts of the Rent Control Ordinance or the Tenant Protection Act. For example, if your landlord does a \"no fault\" eviction, the landlord must follow the Tenant Protection Act and give you a known address for service of process and deposit any and all rent checks you have given him. Under certain circumstances, the landlord also must give you a \"relocation fee.\" If the landlord fails to do this, he is not following the Tenant Protection Act and you can assert an affirmative defense.     Some of the other reasons that are not \"just cause\" are unlawful rent increases; failure to repair; unlawful rent control increases; and that the \"just cause\" ordinance does not apply to your property.   If you are being evicted and need legal help, call 1-866-OUR-LAWYER (1-866-687-5297) to see if you are eligible for free legal help.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"This affirmative defense may be used when a landlord brings an unlawful detainer action against a tenant. In particular, this defense may be used when a landlord brings an unlawful detainer action to recover possession, claiming a fault in the rental agreement, such as failure to pay rent or violation of a provision of the rental agreement, and the landlord is required to comply with provisions of the Rent Control Ordinance and/or the Tenant Protection Act. Under the law, a landlord must prove that they complied with all of the provisions of those laws prior to unlawful detainer. This affirmative defense asks the court to dismiss the unlawful detainer action because the landlord failed to comply with the laws.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

Notice that the landlord has failed to meet one or more of his or her obligations; and    2. Repair the condition and deduct the reasonable cost of the repair from the rent.          In determining whether the tenant gave an appropriate notice to the landlord (the first element), the tenant must show that he or she gave notice to the landlord in a timely manner, clearly stating what conditions as defined by law or by the lease agreement had occurred, and gave the landlord an opportunity to take corrective action. In determining whether the repair costs (the second element) are reasonable, the tenant must show that he or she obtained at least one good faith estimate of the cost of the repair before undertaking the repair, or had a good faith reason for not obtaining the estimate, and that the actual repair is consistent with the estimate in type and quality.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is the jury instruction for Affirmative Defenseâ€”Landlordâ€™s Refusal of Rent?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"An \"affirmative defense\" is a defense in which the defendant attempts to justify his conduct by showing the existence of facts that excuse its wrongfulness. Affirmative defenses may be found in the wrongfulness of the conduct or in matters independent of the conduct. Upon pleading a justification, the defendant has the burden of proving it by a preponderance of the evidence. An affirmative defense most commonly claimed in cases like this is a justification.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Affirmative Defense--Landlord's Refusal of Rent       A landlord who wishes to end a tenancy because a tenant has violated part of the rental agreement must give the tenant a written notice specifying the violation if it is capable of being corrected. If the violation is one that can be corrected, the tenant shall have 30 days to correct it after receiving the notice. If the violation is one that cannot be corrected, it is over after the landlord serves the notice; or after 10 days if the tenant fails to accept the delivery of the notice. If the violation is either corrected or ended after the landlord executes the notice, then the landlord may not file an action for rent that accrues during that time unless the rent is separately due according to the terms of the rental agreement. You may find this an affirmative defense to an action for rent.    Revised Jury Instructions, NUJI 15.34 Landlord's Right to Terminate the Tenancy; Exceptions.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSEâ€”LANDLORD'S REFUSAL OF RENT The defendants in this case have asserted an affirmative defense entitled landlord's refusal of rent. Jones asserts this defense. An affirmative defense is not simply a denial; it is a new matter that in itself would defeat an otherwise valid claim. If a defendant asserts an affirmative defense by claiming to have a special right or privilege, the burden is on the defendant to convince you that the defense has been proved. The defendants have the burden of proving this defense by a preponderance of the evidence. A preponderance of the evidence means that it is more likely than not that the defense is true. In order to prevail on the affirmative defense of landlord's refusal of rent, the defendants must prove all of the following: (1) The landlord refused to accept rent payments; and (2) The plaintiff was willing to pay rent at the time it was due.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

Nothing in the Zinnerman case indicated that a defendant could raise failure to provide reasonable accommodation as an affirmative defense and, therefore, the claim that an employer was entitled to such a defense was without merit. Hills Dept. Store, 60 F.2d 399 (4th Cir. 1995). prompt: What is the principle of Damages for Reasonable Rental Value?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you suffer a property loss due to an insured peril, you may be entitled to additional coverage based on the \"reasonable rental value\" of the damaged property. This benefit covers the loss of \"fair earnings from property\" which means that if you were renting the property and cannot rent it due its loss or damage, you may recover the rent loss. For example, section II of a homeowners policy provides coverage for loss of reasonable rental value of a home. This coverage can apply to the portion of the home, such as a basement apartment, which can be rented to others. However, the coverage only applies up to $1,000 per month, up to a maximum limit of $2,000 for the entire loss.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When an item is lost, stolen, destroyed, or damaged, the principle of damages for reasonable rental value applies. This means, if possible, the party who caused the loss, theft, destruction, or damage must let the owner use a reasonable substitute until the item is replaced or fixed. For example, if you own a car that is stolen, the person who stole it must pay to rent a substitute car for you.    If an item is destroyed, no substitute is available. prompt: What does Statutory Damages on Showing of Malice (Code Civ. Proc., Â§ 1174(b)) require under the law?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"This law deals with a type of defamation, which is a false statement that injures someone's reputation. There are two types of defamation: a lie about a person that is spoken is slander; a lie about a person that is written or published is libel. An example of libel is a newspaper article containing false information about a specific person.    Normally when one sues for defamation, the person must prove that the statement was false and that the one who made it was negligent (he or she did not use enough care to make sure the statement was true). In his or her complaint, the person must also identify all damages that he or she is seeking.    Under the law relating to qualified or official privileges(see Code of Civil Procedure section 1170(b)), a \"privilege\" is an exception to the general rule that a person must prove each element of defamation. The purpose of these exceptions is to encourage certain kinds of communication that benefit the public, even though they could harm a person's reputation. For example, when the legislature writes a speech stating that a particular person has done something bad, no one can sue for defamation.    Under this law, a qualified or official privilege can become lost and a person who uses it can become liable for damages. For example, if during his or her speech in the legislature, a legislator knowingly states a false and malicious lie about a person, the legislator loses his or her legislative immunity and can be sued for the damages caused by the lie.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: How is Reduced Rent for Breach of Habitability explained to the jury?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When a landlord is required to provide habitable premises, the landlord must comply with both the housing and the building codes. The premises must have basic facilities that are safe. Utilities such as sewage, electricity and heat must be supplied. The premises must be capable of being heated. For example, if there is no thermometer, a landlord does not have to keep the temperature at 70 degrees, but the premises must be able to be heated so that they are livable.  Whenever a rental agreement provides for a certain amount of rent, part of that rent is payment for the landlord's obligation to supply the premises in a habitable condition. If the landlord breaches that obligation, then the tenant is obligated to pay a reduced amount of rent. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Article 39 of the United Nations' Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) establishes a global definition of trade secrets. The TRIPS agreement states:  \"Members shall protect undisclosed information in accordance with paragraph 2 and test data submitted to governments or government agencies in accordance with paragraph 3.  2. Undisclosed information - Undisclosed information shall be protected if it :        a) is secret in the sense that it is not, as a body or in the precise configuration and assembly of its components, generally known among or readily accessible to persons within the circles that normally deal with the kind of information in question;     b) has commercial value because it is secret; and     c) has been subject to reasonable steps, under the circumstances, to keep it secret.       3. In addition, Members shall protect such data against disclosure, except where necessary to protect the public, or unless steps are taken to ensure that the data are protected against unfair commercial use.\"   Economic espionage alone is not against the law. Only when economic espionage targets a legally defined trade secret is it a violation of United States law.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Trade Secret Law: Trade Secrets Defined - Defend Trade Secrets Act of 2016 (DTSA) - Uniform Trade Secrets Act (UTSA) - Economic Espionage Act (EEA) The federal Defend Trade Secrets Act of 2016 (DTSA), the widely adopted Uniform Trade Secrets Act (UTSA), and the Economic Espionage Act of 1996 (EEA) all define trade secret based on the following three characteristics: (1) the information had independent economic value from not being known to others, (2) the owner had taken reasonable steps to keep the information secret, (3) the information was not generally known or ascertainable. Trade Secret vs. Copyright vs. Patent Copyright, patents, and trade secrets are all ways of protecting intellectual property (IP). The main difference between them is that copyright and patent law protect what is known to the public, while trade secret law helps keep certain things secret. With copyright and patent protection, you must disclose what they are. For example, when you patent a new kind of pen, you disclose how it works. You get the exclusive right to make, use, or sell that pen for a limited time. Trade secret protection does not have a time limit, but you can lose the protection. If you disclose the secret, somebody else finds out about it, or makes it on their own, it is no longer protected. When you develop a new pen, you do not tell anybody how it works. If somebody finds out how it works, you can no longer protect it.    Trade secret law has the fewest restrictions on what kind of knowledge can be protected. Copyright law only protects expression, so it does not protect ideas, facts, systems, or methods of operation. Patent law protects inventions and only protects the specific ways to accomplish your result, but you have to let the public know what those ways are. Trade secret law protects formulas, patterns, physical devices, and iterated recipes for getting a certain result, but only if they remain secret. DuckDuckGo's search algorithm is a trade secret. Underdigitalized is not a trade secret. The fact that it is underdigitalized is publicly known. Trade Secret Protection Trade secret protection lasts as long as the secret keeps its economic value from not being generally known. Once a trade secret is stolen, it is usually hard to get it back and the owner often loses the competitive advantage. Good trade secret protection requires that a company treat a secret as economic property by having adequate physical and electronic security, supervising employees, limiting access to the secret, and training employees on security and how to protect trade secrets. It also means having good contracts with employees and contractors that include confidentiality and noncompetition clauses.   DTSA, UTSA, and EEA Trade secret law varies by state. Some states passed trade secret laws before 1979, but in 1979, a group of state lawmakers developed a model act to unify the trade secret laws of the states. They called this the Uniform Trade Secrets Act, (UTSA) and it has been updated a few times to keep up with the times. Forty-five states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands have all adopted this law, some with slight variations, some without.    When Congress passed the Economic Espionage Act of 1996 (EEA), it made trade secret misappropriation a federal crime. This was primarily to address economic espionage. In 2016, Congress passed the Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA). This law permits a company to file civil trade secret misappropriation claims in federal court. Source: Legal Information Institute, Cornell Law School","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

A prime example concerns an employee of a company who steals confidential information from the company, and trades on the basis of that information. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The underlying concepts of trade secret and of \"use\" thereof arise under common law. In Kewanee Oil Co. v. Bicron Corp., 416 U.S. 470 (1974), the U.S. Supreme Court recognized a strong public policy favoring trade secret protection. However, trade secrets are not created by federal law; rather, state law governs their creation and enforceability. The Uniform Trade Secret Act (sale version) is adopted (at least in part) by most states, and has been adopted in its entirety by 34 states, including California, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Hawaii, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kentucky, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, North Dakota, Ohio, Oregon, South Carolina, Tennessee, Utah, Vermont, Washington and Wisconsin. The draft article, which was proposed to the Assembly and plenary organs of the League of Nations in 1925, as a possible basis for a unilateral declaration to make success in naval warfare, deals principally with the misappropriation of flags....\" The principle explains that misappropriation by use or theft may be committed by \"a person, corporate entity or a state...\" The principle states: \"Tatiana's Treaties is the property and trademark of Tatiana's Treaties Corp. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The Trade Practices Act 1974 supports misappropriation by use. The Trade Practices Act prohibits various forms of misleading and deceptive conduct in connection with trade or commerce, including conduct involving misappropriation of property. Misappropriation of property is a form of conversion that occurs when the owner of the property has either expressly or impliedly consented to a specific use, but it is later used for a different purpose. For example, allowing the use of a sledgehammer to remove tree stumps is an express consent to a specific use. If that sledgehammer is later used as a weapon against a person, that is a misappropriation conduct.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

Seinfeld  In the New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division, a doctor sued a comedian, alleging that he stole his idea for a fictional character and used it on his television show. Degenshein had previously performed as a stand-up comedian under the stage name Andy Kopfgstatz and invented the character \"Fat MacArthur,\" a tour guide at the United Nations, for his act. Jerry Seinfeld portrayed a character that shared some similarities with the doctor on an episode of Seinfeld as a United Nations tour guide: McDonald. The complaint alleged that Jerry Seinfeld and Seinfeld co-creator Larry David \"misappropriated plaintiff's goodwill\" by incorporating the character into one episode of Seinfeld. Degenshein also alleged violations of the right of publicity, the Lanham Act, unfair competition, common law misappropriation, and tortious interference with employment agreements.   The court dismissed the complaint. The court noted that the United Nations tour guide character was one of many on Seinfeld who were \"clearly...broad parodies intended to poke fun at various facets of human nature,\" and that there is no indication that the episode \"targeted, referred to, or slandered\" Degenshein. Degenshein may have been upset about the character that was made fun of in the episode but the court stated that \"parody...is not the same thing as defamation.\" The court concluded that Degenshein had failed to state a cause of action for misappropriation because his professional goodwill was not uniquely associated with the \"Fat MacArthur\" character; nor was the \"Fat MacArthur\" character a single exclusive business. Degenshein v. Seinfeld, 4 A.D.3d 245, 771 N.Y.S.2d 445 (N.Y. App. Div. 2004).   2. Gamer's Edge v. Cole  Gamer's Edge (GE) developed golf video games and licensed patent rights to developers worldwide. GE motioned for a preliminary injunction against a Florida gaming company, Cobra Golf, alleging that Cobra and its owner, Dan Cole, copied and used patented GE golf video game innovations in a way that exceeded the license agreement between the parties and constituted infringement. GE established that the patents in suit were valid and that the Cobra products were infringing. GE further demonstrated that Cobra had used some GE documents without permission to aid Cobra's development of infringing products. Showing that GE's licensed patent rights constituted a protectable property interest and that the unauthorized use of GE's documents could cause irreparable harm to GE, the court granted GE's motion for a preliminary injunction. GE was ordered to give Cobra 30-days notice of the time at which GE would begin requiring Cobra's compliance with the license agreement.   Later, GE filed a motion for contempt of court against Cobra and Cole alleging that they violated the preliminary injunction by continuing to computer program and develop the infringing product. The court held that GE had met its burden to establish that the products were illegally infringing GE's license. The court found that GE had not met its burden to show irreparable harm because GE did not submit evidence of any lost sales or capacity. prompt: What are the elements of the Unjust Enrichment?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"There are three essential elements of an unjust enrichment: (1) the defendant has been enriched; (2) the enrichment is at the plaintiff's expense; and (3) the enrichment is unjust. Concerning the third element, converse situations may render an enrichment unjust. Examples of converse situations that have been held to be unjust include a detriment without a corresponding legal ground (see Raab Jr. V. Sullivan, 73 AD3d 1265, 901 N.Y.S.2d 765(2010)), or a recovery on the ground that there is an interest in preventing unjust enrichment (see Jersey City Fed. Credit Union v. Twp. of Brick, 190 N.J. Super. 202, 463 A.2d 937(1983)).","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The elements of the unjust enrichment cause of action are the following:       - The plaintiff gave the defendant a benefit;    - The defendant realized or appreciated that benefit; and    - Under the circumstances it is unjust for the defendant to retain the benefit without compensating the plaintiff for it.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"To prove a claim of unjust enrichment, a person must show four elements, sometimes called the four corners of the claim:        - That he conferred a benefit (such as property or money) to the defendant;    - That the defendant had knowledge of the benefit;     - That the defendant accepted or retained the benefit; and     - That it would be inequitable for the defendant to retain the benefit without paying for it. prompt: What is the legal standard for the Independent Economic Value Explained?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Divorce is often unfair to one or both spouses, at least in some economic sense. Each spouse's independent economic value is an attempt to quantify that unfairness. Independent economic value is not a well known term, but it is related to the concept of non-marital property. Non-marital property is a property the parties owned prior to marriage or which they acquired by gift or inheritance. Spouses are entitled to keep their non-marital property after they are divorced. Economic value is the worth of that property at the time of divorce. Independent economic value is the economic value of a spouse's non-marital property after divorce.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The independent economic value of a water right is the economic value of the consumptive use of a water right existing independent of the value of any associated water or wastewater facilities.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The independent test is one of five tests used to determine whether intangible property is capital (personal) or ordinary. Capital (personal) intangible property has independent economic value if the property has value from some use other than its use in the trade or business in which it is currently being used or intended to be used.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The determination of an appropriate discount rate for discounting future cash flows to present value is guided by the selection of a standard of value to be applied in the valuation. The standard of value for our valuation indication is investment value. The discount rate for investment value should reflect the specific benefits and burdens of the investment to the particular investor for whom the investment value is calculated. Part of the investment's risks to an investor include market risk specific to the investment included in, or excluded from, quantification elsewhere in the valuation. Because the components of market risk included/excluded differ among investors, an appropriate discount rate for investment value will vary by investor and over time.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When an asset is income producing, its highest and best use can be established using an income valuation approach. This approach uses an asset's ability to generate income as the basis for its valuation. An income valuation approach can be through discounted cash flow or capitalization of earnings. An asset's income generating ability is established through income statements and balance sheets which show the asset's net income during a period of time.   The most common income valuation approach is capitalization of earnings. Capitalization of earnings is a process of estimating the present worth of a future stream of earnings by converting a series of future earnings into an indication of value by dividing one year's excess earnings by an appropriate rate of return.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"In a breach of implied warranty of correctness of plans and specifications case, a plaintiff must prove that:         1. plans or specifications furnished by the defendant were to be used by the plaintiff to build some specified structure, system or improvement on the land in question and were incorrect;     2. the defendant impliedly warranted that the plans and specifications were correct, suitable, fit, and sufficient for the intended purpose;     3. the plaintiff relied in a reasonable manner on this warranty by using the plans and specifications in the construction work; and     4. defects and other problems ensued because the plans and specifications provided were incorrect.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Instruction 341 provides a definition of a \"breach of implied warranty of correctness of plans and specifications.\" In addition, the instruction gives the elements necessary to establish that breach.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Breaches of implied warranties are defined in Chapter 20 of the Business and Professions Code. There, the Legislature declares that the statutes impose upon all people working in certain trades related to homes, a warranty that the work will meet minimum standards for skill and safety. For example, the workmanship needs to be consistent with \"building standards and codes....\" Section 7191 states: \"A licensee who undertakes to furnish the services described in this chapter ... warrants that the licensee shall perform the services in a manner consistent with the standards of care, skill, and diligence normally provided by members of the licensee's profession actively practicing in California.... A licensee shall be responsible for a negligent act ... in the same manner as would be a person who was not licensed.\"    An implied warranty is an automatic promise created by law. It is different from an express warranty, which is a promise that the seller makes in words about the quality or functionality of the goods being sold. The seller may also make express warranties through brochures or ads. Implied warranties, however, are not written. They are not spoken. You cannot see them. They are based on what the law presumes is in a contract.    Under the law, there is an implied warranty of merchantability. This means that goods they are selling meet a minimum level of quality. They will work for the ordinary, particular purpose for which they are sold. For example, carrots must be firm and ripe enough for eating. But, any carrots vary in quality and size. Buyers also rely on an implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose. This means that if they buy goods for a particular purpose and tell this to the seller, the goods should be fit for the purpose. If an individual buys a car for racing and tells this to the seller, the car should be fit for that purpose. Implied warranties apply to both new and used goods.    Specifications are a detailed description of the design or materials used to make something. Plans are detailed diagrams, drawings or blueprints that show how something should be made or put together.    Breach of Implied Warranty of Correctness of Plans and Specifications means that the plans and specifications didn't meet the warranty.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The right to a jury instruction arises from the substantive law. A and B entered into a valid contract calling for B to perform certain work according to plans and specifications identified in the contract; 2. A did not know that the plans and specifications used for the job were not reasonably suitable for the job when A entered into the contract; 3. The plans and specifications used for the job were not reasonably suitable for the job; and 4. B suffered damage as a result. This set of instructions is merely a short description of the elements of Breach of Implied Warranty of Correctness of Plans and Specifications.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is the jury instruction for Affirmative Defenseâ€”Contractor Followed Plans and Specifications?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Affirmative Defense - Contractor Followed Plans and Specifications If a contractor has a contract with an owner to construct improvements on the owner's property, the contractor has a duty to use reasonable care to build the improvements according to the plans and specifications provided to the contractor. If the contractor follows those plans and specifications, the contractor's duty to use reasonable care is satisfied. Plaintiffs claim that _______________________. Defendants assert that the contractor followed the plans and specifications that were provided to the contractor. If you find that the contractor followed those plans and specifications, then your verdict should be for the defendants. Instruction 13.27 - Alabama Civil Pattern Jury Instructions","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Affirmative Defense-Contractor Followed Plans and Specifications requires a separate finding on appeal under Nebraska law. Schmidlin v. BelAire Ins. Co., 281 Neb. 906, 791 N.W.2d 238 (2010). The Committee on Model Jury Instructions - Civil recommends the following instruction: This is an action for damages. The plaintiff claims [describe claim]. The defendant denies the plaintiff's claim and further states that it followed plans and specifications provided by [name]. It is an affirmative defense that you must find to be proved by a preponderance of the evidence. If you decide that the plaintiff is entitled to recover damages in this case, you must consider whether defendant proved that it followed plans and specifications provided by [name]. If you find that defendant proved that it followed plans and specifications provided by [name], it is a defense to plaintiff's claim.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Affirmative Defense--Contractor Followed Plans and Specifications\nYou have heard evidence that the builder who contracted for the construction or remodeling of a house did not personally take part in some of the decisions concerning the construction or remodeling, and followed the plans and specifications made by others. If the builder did so, you must consider that evidence along with all other evidence in the case. If you accept all of that evidence, then the builder may not be responsible for any breach of the warranty of good and workmanlike construction resulting from the construction or remodeling work or decisions not actually undertaken or made by the builder.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Affirmative Defense-Contractor Followed Plans and Specifications\nYou have heard evidence of affirmative defense of a contractor that followed plans and specifications. An affirmative defense is a defense that is based on matters other than the facts that create the plaintiffâ€™s right to recover. It is a defense that if established by the defendant will defeat or mitigate the legal consequences of the defendant's otherwise wrongful conduct.     On the plaintiff's claim that the defendant made certain defects in a home, the defendant asserts that the defects are due to the fact that someone followed the plans and specifications when building the home. \"Following plans and specifications\" means that the person who built the home did not substantially add to, subtract or change.       If you find that the defendant followed the plans and specifications, then you must find for the defendant. In any event, the burden is on the defendant to prove by a preponderance of evidence that the defendant followed the plans and specifications.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Affirmative Defense-Contractor Followed Plans and Specifications     If you find that the plans and specifications used by [name of contractor] to construct the [structure] were inadequate and that the inadequacy was a cause of [claimant's] injury, then your verdict should be for the defendants, even if you find that [name of contractor] followed the plans and specifications correctly. prompt: What case law supports Affirmative Defenseâ€”Contractor Followed Plans and Specifications?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When a property owner claims that loss or damage was caused by negligent construction, an affirmative defense may be that the contractor followed plans and specifications. There are a couple of scenarios which may invoke this affirmative defense. Contractor may be hired for a task such as installing an air conditioner, and the specifications for the installation are provided by the manufacturer, not the owner.  Another related scenario is when the contractor performed as agreed in the contract, for example, to build a 6-foot fence based on written specifications provided by the owner, and a neighbor's child climbs the fence and injures himself. This guide addresses the first scenario.  To raise this affirmative defense, contractor will have to prove that he followed the plans and specifications exactly. Furthermore, courts have ruled that when there is not a defect in the plans, the contractor is not liable for any damages or injuries that occur. And when the parties to the contract are in dispute, courts have ruled â€śthat a party cannot escape his obligations upon a claim that the other failed to perform his part unless that other party failed to perform a condition precedent to such obligations. In other words, that obligee must perform, or be ready to perform, his obligations under the contract before the obligor is excused or discharged from performing his obligations.â€ť Linder v. Bay Harbor Townhouses, LLC, 2009 NCBC 4 (N.C. Business Court 2009).  Note: You may wish to consult an attorney if you want to attempt to raise this affirmative defense.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Case law indicates that a contractor may be liable for construction defects if the contractor did not follow plans and/or specifications.
