(813 A.2d 940 (R.I., 2003)), where the Rhode Island Supreme Court held that a building contractor was held liable to a municipality for construction defects because the contractor failed to follow intended plans and well-recognized civil engineering practices for water drainage system.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: How is Contractorâ€™s Claim for Changed or Extra Work explained to the jury?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Contractor's claims for changed or extra work are claims that a property owner or manager has altered the agreed upon job in some way. A change might be an instruction to make a change relative to size, design, materials, or workmanship specified in the original job. Sometimes this is referred to as a constructive change. A change might also be an instruction to delay the work or to stop the work. Extra work might be work that the original contract did not call for at all.  Changing or making extra work can affect the job. It might make it take more or less time or it might raise or lower the cost. It is reasonable that the contractor will seek to be compensated for increased costs and overhead expenses such as additional salaries, rent, additional trucks and fringes. It is reasonable that the party who requested a change should bear the cost of it.  The contractor has the burden of proving that the owner is responsible for the increased expenses. The contractor must produce competent evidence of the amount of the damages.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When you are a construction contractor, you and the owner of the property you're working on make an agreement. The agreement is called a contract. The contract says what the owner wants built, where the money is coming from, and how much the contractor is to be paid. The contract may also contain provisions about design of the project and when work is to be done. The contract may be written or oral.    Some contracts contain a provision that either party can ask that the contract be changed or \"modified.\"    But sometimes the owner, the contractor, or the workers who are working for the contractor, want the contract changed.    The contractor gives the owner written notice of the desired change or extra work. The notice includes a description of the change or extra work and a sum of money required to do the change or extra work.    The contractor claims to be entitled to money beyond the contract price for the additional work. The increase or decrease in the contract price depends on the amount of extra work and any work the contractor agrees to omit. The change or extra work can be a change in          - Plans and specifications,    - Method or kind of work,    - Quantity of work or materials to be furnished, or    - Time for completion of the contract       If the owner, the workers, or the inspector fails to recognize the work as extra work, the contractor is entitled to no additional compensation.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"In all construction projects, contractors and property owners want to work harmoniously. When there is disagreement about the job, the contractor might file a lawsuit.    To win the lawsuit, the contractor must prove that the owner agreed to a job different in some material way from what was originally contracted for. The contractor must also be able to prove that the change resulted in a cost above or below what the contract price initially called for.    This issue explains how to prepare this claim. It is one of the claims used in construction cases, and you should read and understand all of them.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The Instructional Fair 2003 districts have adapted several of the American Jury Instructions for Use in Construction Defect Litigation, which were developed by the State Bar of California's Section of Litigation, Construction Litigation Committee. These instructions are designed to help you as a juror understand the legal concepts you will be hearing during the trial. You can find other helpful instructions on topics such as \"Negligence,\" \"Causation,\" and \"Comparative fault.\"","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you decide that a contractor was entitled to extra compensation for additional work, you must find the amount of the extra compensation. To make this calculation, you will also need to make three findings:        - The value of the extra work;     - The amount that the owner has already paid for the extra work; and     - The amount the contractor has paid to subcontractors for the extra work.        The \"value of the extra work\" is the increased cost to the contractor for the work and a reasonable margin or mark-up.    In making a claim for compensation for additional work, the contractor must properly account for amounts received from the owner and paid to subcontractors. This means the contractor has the burden of showing how much the owner has already paid for the extra work and how much the contractor has paid to subcontractors. Documentary evidence is one way to show that amounts were paid.    Instructions to the jury are set forth at California Civil Jury Instructions (CACI) No. 3335.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: How is Ownerâ€™s Claim That Contract Procedures Regarding Change Orders Were Not Followed explained to the jury?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"A contract between a property owner and a contractor may require the contractor to get the owner's written approval to modify the contract, including an increase in the contract price, before the contractor may do the work. Owners often consider the purpose of this requirement is to prevent the contractor from modifying the contract without their knowledge and consent.   Contractors often consider the purpose of this requirement is to protect them from performing work and later being told that the owner did not approve or accept the work, and from not being paid for work that is outside the contract. If the owner approves the changed work, the contractor usually is entitled to be paid for it. If the owner does not approve the changed work, the contractor, if it performs the work, usually does so at is own risk.   Sometimes contractors submit certain changed work to the owner for approval but do not get the approval before performing the work. This does not necessarily preclude the contractor from obtaining compensation for the work.   This explanation was taken from the TWCC Model Jury Charge on Owner's Claim That Contract Procedures Regarding Change Orders Were Not Followed (CC1(f)).","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What case law supports Ownerâ€™s Claim That Contract Procedures Regarding Change Orders Were Not Followed?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Relevant case law addresses an ownerâ€™s claim that contract procedures regarding change orders were not followed. For example, in the Federal Circuit case of Merit Management Contractors, Inc. v. United States, the appeals court determined dispute review board procedures were mandatory and therefore the contractor was not entitled to recover without following them. On appeal from the Court of Federal Claims, the Federal Circuit affirmed the Court of Federal Claims' dismissal of Merit Management's complaint for failing to exhaust dispute resolution procedures in the parties contract. The Court of Federal Claims determined that the parties dispute resolution procedures were mandatory because the contract expressly stated the procedures were to be followed, the procedures were not inconsistent with the contract other than with respect to cost determination, and the dispute resolution procedures did not conflict with the Contract Disputes Act - which requires certain procedures to be followed to preserve jurisdiction. The Federal Circuit thus held that a federal contractor is not entitled to recover on contract claims that were not first submitted for dispute resolution under contract procedures. prompt: How is Waiver of Written Approval or Notice Requirements for Changed or Additional Work explained to the jury?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The waiver of written approval or notice requirements for changed or additional work is an indication that you agree that the contractor may proceed with the changed work or additional work without your prior written approval or notice. A change to, or additional work under, a construction contract often requires the written approval of the owner before the contractor may proceed with the work. Additionally, the right to the reimbursement of costs relating to the change or additional work may require the owner to give the contractor written notice approving the change or additional work before the owner is obligated to reimburse the contractor for the cost of the change or additional work. In some cases, individuals undertaking construction contracts may waive these requirements. This allows the contractor to proceed with the work without any prior written approval or notice. However, if the work is not ordered by the owner, the owner is not obligated to pay the contractor for the additional work.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"In most construction contracts, the owner agrees not to unreasonably withhold the owner's approval of any changed or additional work proposed by the contractor. Some contracts also require the owner to approve in writing any changed or additional work that exceeds a certain dollar amount. If the contract requires this written approval and the owner agrees to changed or additional work without approval, the owner is said to have waived the requirement of written approval for that changed or additional work.    In some construction contracts, the contractor agrees not to unreasonably withhold any approval that the contract requires the owner to provide. Some contracts also require the owner to provide notice before taking certain actions. If the owner fails to provide the required notice and the contractor agrees to the owner's actions, the contractor is said to have waived the requirement for that notice.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

The following is provided for your information only.    If you decide that the contract was abandoned by the City, you must then consider the issue of the amount that the Contractor is entitled to as additional compensation.    The Contractor must prove, by a preponderance of the evidence, the amount of additional compensation that it claims that it is entitled to receive as a result of abandonment. A \"preponderance of the evidence\" means it is more likely than not. The Contractor must prove both the amount claimed and that it is properly recoverable. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you find that there is a breach of the contract, you must determine the amount of money, if any, that the owner is entitled to recover because of the breach. Complete the following questions to determine if the owner is entitled to recover money damages for the unaccepted work:       - Was the owner required to accept and pay for all of the work that does not conform to the contract? Answer: No. The owner was not required to accept and pay for all of the work that does not conform to the contract.     - Did the amount of unaccepted work or deficiency exceed a minor part of the entire contract? Answer: Yes.    - Would the unaccepted work substantially impair the value of the entire contract? Answer: Yes.       If you answered all three questions as indicated above, the owner is entitled to recover damages for the unaccepted work. With regard to the amount the owner is entitled to recover, there are two alternative methods of calculating damages. The first is based on the diminution in market value of the property as a result of the unaccepted work. The second is the cost to repair the unaccepted work. The owner is entitled to recover the lesser of the two amounts. Complete the following questions to determine the diminution in market value of the property as a result of the unaccepted work:       - Did the contract involve preexisting property of the owner?    - If question 1 was answered \"yes\": Was the value of the preexisting property, without improvements, to be the basis for measuring damages?     - If question 2 was answered \"yes\": Is it established that the value of the preexisting property, without improvements, is the basis for measuring damages? Answer: Not established.       Complete the following questions to determine the cost to cure or repair the unaccepted work:       - Did the owner cause an appraisal to be made of the property in order to determine the cost to cure or repair? If yes, the cost to cure or repair is the amount of that appraisal.    - If the owner did not cause an appraisal to be made or the amount of the appraisal is not in evidence: If repair is reasonably possible, could it be done in such manner that it would not reduce the value of the property more than the cost of such repair?    - If question 2 was answered \"yes\": Can repair be done at a reasonable cost?    - If repair can be done at a reasonable cost: Will the reduction in value of the property, taking into account such repair, be greater than the cost of such repair?    - If the reduction in value of the property, taking into account such repair, is not greater than the cost of such repair: Is the cost of a substitute necessary to replace unaccepted work reasonably ascertainable?     - If the cost of a substitute is reasonably ascertainable: Is the cost to acquire and install a reasonably suitable substitute, as compared to the unaccepted work, the cost of such a substitute?    - If the cost of a substitute is not reasonably ascertainable or the cost of a substitute is not the cost to acquire and install a reasonably suitable substitute: Is the cost of replacement of the unaccepted work with similar work, as compared to the unaccepted work, the cost of such replacement?       - If question 1 was answered \"no\", question 6 was answered \"no\", question 7 was answered \"no\", and question 9(a) was answered \"no\": Is the cost of the repair the amount of that injury?       The owner is entitled to recover the lesser of the diminution in market value and the cost to repair. It is the amount of money, if any, specified in either the diminution in market value or the cost to repair, whichever is less.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

If you are the owner of a project and a contractor fails to complete the project on schedule you may have a claim for damages for the delay. If you have suffered damages, you have to prove them to recover. Liquidated damages are damages fixed in advance and stated in the contract. prompt: What does Contractorâ€™s Damages for Breach of Construction Contractâ€”Change Orders/Extra Workâ€”Total Cost Recovery require under the law?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The laws and regulations under which the Department of General Services (DGS) operates mandate that changes to construction work shall be made only it if is in the public interest. That is why DGS has a policy allowing construction contractors to request a change order for extra work only when the change is required by the architect, contractor, or by federal, state or local laws or regulations.   If a change order does require extra work that impacts the scope of work, construction cost and/or construction schedule, a construction contractor may request an extension of time and/or additional money to which it is entitled.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If the owner asks you to perform work outside the scope of the original construction contract, you and the owner should agree on the details of the additional work before you start the work. You should put the agreement in writing, since construction contracts generally require all modifications to be in writing. The writing should include the change order number, describe the additional work and state the agreed-to price.    Sometimes, things that you perform are considered to be additional work but the owner does not ask for them. If so, you should also get an agreement in writing before you begin the work. When the owner acknowledges that you were correct to have done the work and that he wants it, the owner has authorized the work, but you may still want to get a written agreement of the details of the additional work and the price.    If the owner requests the additional work and agrees with you on the details, but you do not have a signed contract, you should put the details you agreed on in writing or confirm them in writing. This may be helpful in case of a dispute.    If you believe the owner is asking you to perform additional work that will result in extra cost to you, you must notify the owner of the additional cost before the work commences.    Likewise, if unforeseen factors cause you to believe your cost will exceed the agreed-on change order price, you should notify the owner prior to the work being completed.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Under the law, contractor's damages for breach of contract must be proved with reasonable certainty. However, proof of damages need not be perfect, and a plaintiff may recover if a preponderance of the evidence supports the damages sought. Strict accounting is not required. In any case, the burden is on the contractor to prove its damages.   The contractor may recover damages for a breach of a construction contract in several different ways. If the breach involved the owner's failure to pay contract price, the contractor may recover under a theory of quantum meruit, that is, the reasonable value of the services actually and knowingly performed. Alternatively, the contractor may recover on a theory of unjust enrichment, that is, there is no contract but the owner would be unjustly enriched if it were allowed to keep the benefit of the contractor's work without paying for it. In addition, the contractor may recover the contract price under a theory of breach of contract, even if the work was not completed (subject to certain exceptions).   In order to recover under the contract, the contractor must establish it substantially performed the contract. The contractor may recover even if it did not perform all of the contract requirements, but in that event, the owner may offset from the contract price the cost to complete the contract. Courts will generally not require precise performance if the contractor substantially performed the contract. Alteration contracts, however, are usually interpreted so as to require strict performance.   In addition to the contract price, contractors may recover damages for extra work or changes ordered by the owner, as well as for time extensions or other modifications of the contract. These are essentially claims for \"extras,\" and the contractor must comply with the procedural and formal requirements of the contract (such as providing a written request for the extra, a formal change order signed by the owner, specification of the amount and basis of the change, and similar requirements). Additional requirements may be  of extras. For example, when extras are work of a type specifically excluded from the contract, the contractor may recover even if it does not follow the contract's procedure for changes. When extras are rejections of part of the work as not conforming to contract requirements, the contractor may also recover them without compliance with the contract's change procedure.   The cost of extras to the contractor may be based on the contract schedule of values, the contractor's price list or other similar document, or on the actual cost of performance. When the time to complete the contract has been exceeded, the contractor is also entitled to costs which have increased because of the delay. When the contract has been suspended and restarted, the contractor is entitled to the increased costs due to the suspension and on restarting plus any lost profits on the portion of the work laid off during the suspension. When the amount claimed includes amounts for indirect costs, \"home office\" expenses or the cost of performance of unauthorized work, the owner is entitled to offsets for value received, for the claim and for amounts not supported by documentary evidence. The owner may also set off from the contract balance any claim the owner has against the contractor.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: How should a jury apply Contractorâ€™s Damages for Abandoned Construction Contractâ€”Quantum Meruit Recovery?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"A quantum meruit contract is not a contract for work of a particular kind or for a particular price. It entitles a party to recover the value of his work, labor, or services. The measure of damages under quantum meruit is the reasonable value of the services actually performed by the person claiming them in accordance with the contract before the contract was disaffirmed, less any moneys received on account thereof. You should view the work performed under the contract as the equitable basis for recovery. As long as the work has been performed under the contract according to its terms, its value is a proper element in determining the amount of recovery under quantum meruit.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you find that the plaintiff owner abandoned the contract without the defendant contractor's consent, and the owner did not breach the contract, then the contractor does not have a contract claim. However, you might be able to find in favor of the contractor on a claim that the parties had a contract and that something else prevented the contractor from completing the contract.       If you have found that the parties had a contract and that something else prevented the contractor from completing the contract, you must decide the amount of the contractor's recovery under a theory called quantum meruit. Quantum meruit means \"as much as he has earned.\" Under this recovery, the contractor may recover the reasonable value of the work actually done.       I have given you instructions on how to determine the reasonable value of the work actually done and how to determine the amount of damages, if any, to which the contractor is entitled.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The District Court did not err in instructing the jury on the quantum meruit measure of damages. We review jury instructions de novo, construe them as a whole, and view them in the context of the instructions as a whole to determine whether they were misleading or prejudicial. The general principle of unjust enrichment that underlies the quantum meruit measure of damages applies where there is no contract or express agreement between the parties but where the party to be charged has received a benefit from the other party under such circumstances that it would be inequitable for the recipient to retain the benefit without paying for it. United States v. Thornhill Inv., 212 F.3d 530, 538 (10th Cir. 2000). Contractor argues that the court erred in instructing the jury to find the amount of damages Contractor had proven under quantum meruit as compensation for the work Contractor performed on the Belcourt project, more specifically, that the instructions and verdict forms did not account for the \"benefit\" requirement of quantum meruit and did not explicitly state that Tribal Enterprise must have been enriched in order for Contractor to be entitled to damages in the amount it proved. But the benefit requirement is implicit in the instructions. With respect to the amount of damages, the instructions informed the jury that it could award $262,996.14 only if its answer to the preceding question was \"yes,\" a reference to the question that asked the jury to determine whether Contractor had proven that Tribal Enterprise had accepted some of the benefits of the work under the contract. In turn, the verdict form for the claim for quantum meruit awarded Contractor $0 unless the jury found Contractor was entitled to recover on the claims. Because Contractor does not develop any cogent argument with respect to the prejudice requirement under the Tenth Circuit law and Rule 51 of the Federal rules of Civil procedure, it has waived that argument. See Anderson v. U.S., 61 F.3d 1505, 1510 (10th Cir. 1995)(issues raised in skeletal fashion without supporting arguments are deemed abandoned); see also Martin v. Bd. of County Comm'rs, 909 F.2d 402, 406 (10th Cir. 1990)(failure to adequately support an issue in the opening brief results in waiver of the issue). In sum, the court did not err in instructing the jury.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"This principle provides guidance on the damages that a contractor in a construction project is entitled to when an owner causes delay or acceleration in the project. Contractors in construction projects are often damaged by delays or accelerations caused by owners. Contractors sometimes incur damages when the owner causes the contractor to delay some other work, accelerates the work of the contractor, causes the contractor to stop and start work, or issues change orders to the construction contract. This principle explains how to handle those situations. In some cases competent and reasonably careful planning on the part of the owner can reduce the magnitude of delay to the work. Owners can reduce their exposure to liability for damages to the contractor by effective scheduling of the work, timely issuing of change orders, and taking reasonable steps to avoid unnecessary interference with the contractor's work.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When an owner delays the performance of the contract or demands that the work be performed faster than was contemplated in the original schedule, the owner has caused an acceleration of the contract work. Acceleration may be either express or implied. Express acceleration occurs when the owner gives the contractor a notice to accelerate. Implied acceleration occurs when the contract completion date is moved up without the contractor's agreement.        Acceleration increases the contractor's costs, including the cost of additonal labor, over time premium, extra job supervision, overtime, and other costs. The contractor may recover for these damages if the contract includes a \"no damages for delay clause\" and if factors beyond the owner's control also caused delays to the contract. Otherwise, the contractor must also prove that the delays blamed on the owner were not caused by the contractor or the contractor's subcontractors.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

The amount of damages awarded depends on the cause of the delay, the terms of the contract, and state law. Under most laws and contracts, the owner is not liable for delays caused by various types of excusable delays, such as natural disasters or strikes.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When a construction contract is breached, the non-breaching party may be entitled to damages. This may include damages for delay in completion when the owner breaches the contract.  Delay in completion of the contract could be caused by the owner, the contractor, or other forces. Delay of project completion by the owner could entitle the contractor to a time extension. It is possible the contractor could also be entitled to money damages to compensate for costs caused by the delay. These damages are often referred to as \"impact costs.\"  In order to recover damages for delay, a court or jury would likely require evidence that the owner/body breached the contract; that the breach caused the delay; and a reasonable basis for calculating the amount of damages.  Acceleration is the act of speedup up progress. The breaching party may be responsible for the increased cost to the other party for acceleration caused by the breach. For example, if the owner breaches a task order and the breach causes delay to another task order with a later completion date, the contractor may have to accelerate the later task order to meet the original contract completion date. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The following table contains unreported, non-precedential court of appeals opinions that discuss owner-caused delay and acceleration in construction contracts. The summaries are based on a review of the court opinions and limited to the topics at issue in the court cases. Because the cases are unreported and non-precedential, they may have limited value as precedent. Click on the case name to view the court's opinion in PDF format. You may need Adobe Acrobat Reader to view PDF files.  Case Name Summary of Case Roegner Construction Co. v. Ohio Dept. of Transportation, No. 10AP-1604 (Ct. App. Ohio, 10th Dist., 2/8/12) On a fixed price construction contract with the State of Ohio, the contract completion time was extended three times. The contractor argued that additional extensions were warranted for various reasons, some related to delays allegedly caused by the state, some unrelated. The Court of Appeals noted that the record showed that, at various times, the state acted as  the project manager and was responsible for keeping the project on schedule, maintaining a log of working days, and verifying delays. The court noted that it is the role of the engineers and not the courts to determine the number of working days and the date for project completion and that those determinations are binding so long as the engineers complied with the law and did not act arbitrarily or unreasonably. The court found that the state engineers had not acted arbitrarily in finding four contract extensions instead of some other number. The court noted that at least one was apparently in response to a delay caused by the state as owner. Because the project was under a fixed price contract, the court found that the delay did not entitle the contractor to additional compensation. SiteWork Contracting Co. v. Milwaukee Metropolitan Sewerage Dist., No. 2010AP1759 (Wis. Ct. of Appeals, 7th Dist., 3/28/12) The contractor on a construction project sued for delay damages. The contract had a schedule with a final completion date and a liquidated damage clause. Alterations to the work included a time extension of 18 days for completion of the project. The circuit court dismissed the contractor's claims for delay damages. The court of appeals affirmed, finding that because the contract had a liquidated damages provision, which also required substantial completion by the completion date, the contract precluded recovery for delay damages except under certain circumstances which did not apply here. The court further noted that, because the contract had a liquidated damages clause and there was an agreed-upon extension of the work, the contractor was entitled to no additional compensation for delays except damages it could recover for increased costs of performing the contract. The court found that the contractor had not presented evidence of the latter. STI Construction, Inc. v. City of Orem, No. 20090318-CA (Utah Court of Appeals, 10/24/11) A contractor on a city created delay project won summary judgment on its claim for $1,021,320 in additional costs. The contract had a fixed price for performing the work and a liquidated damages provision. The contract said that it was the owner's responsibility to provide access to the work site by specified times, and that the contract time would be adjusted for delays caused by the owner. The project completion date was delayed more than 15 months. The contractor needed to employ more people and pay increased wages due to the extended work schedule. The court noted that, absent a provision for increased labor costs, a contractor does not necessarily bear the risk of owner caused delays. The court also noted that the owner did not contest that the additional costs were reasonable and were related to the extended schedule. The court affirmed an award to the contractor for the extra costs. American Ins. Co. v. Fox Quarry Co., 508 N.W.2d 287 (Neb. 1993) The court found that a contractor was entitled to damages for the increased costs it incurred to perform a contract because of a 35-day delay, an owner-caused acceleration of the contract schedule and a related increase in the contract quantities. The court noted that part of the damages were indirect costs consisting of additional supervision, engineering, and other overhead attributable to the additional work that increased the capacity of the contractor's operations.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is the jury instruction for Contractorâ€™s Damages for Breach of Construction Contractâ€”Inefficiency Because of Owner Conduct?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The following is the jury instruction for contractor's damages for breach of construction contract-inefficiency because of owner conduct: If an owner does something that is in breach of the contract, and that something reduces the efficiency of the contractor's work, the contractor can be awarded damages for the inefficiency. Inefficiency damages are damages that compensate the contractor for the reduction of its ability to perform its work \"efficiently\" or without \"waste.\" You must find that the inefficiency was a reasonably certain consequence of the breach and not too remote or speculative. You may award inefficiency damages either on the basis of a reasonable estimate of the amount of damages or on the basis of the contractor's actual damages. For example, you may award damages based on a reasonable value of additional labor, equipment, or materials required to complete the job because the owner's breach caused inefficiency. Such an award may be in addition to other damages awarded to the contractor. If you find that the contractor could have avoided inefficiency damages by reasonable efforts, you may not award any damages to the contractor for inefficiency that could have been avoided by the contractor's reasonable efforts. You may not award damages for inefficiency ifIt was not a reasonably certain consequence of the owner's breach, or Inefficiency was not reduced or avoided.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When you decide the question of whether the contractor was inefficient because of owner's conduct, consider the following elements:        1. whether the owner hindered the contractor in the performance of the contract;    2. whether the owner failed to cooperate with the contractor; or    3. whether the owner was responsible for changed conditions which interfered with the work.        When you have decided these questions, you must consider any evidence of the contractor's inefficiency because of the conduct of the owner in awarding damages, if any.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Inefficiency Because of Owner Conduct Instruction No. 14.551.00    (April 2007)    If you find that the owner is responsible for a change in the contractor's method of operation, you should consider the effect of that change on the contractor's cost of performance. Before the change, the contractor may have been expected to perform with a level of efficiency; after the change, under the same conditions, the contractor must be expected to perform with a different level of efficiency. If the contract has an efficiency standard, you should consider the effect of the change on any burden of proof imposed by that standard.    For the effect of the owner's conduct on the contractor's damage recovery under certain owner breaching conduct, see instructions discussing that conduct. (See, for example, instructions 14.551.03, 14.552.01, and 14.555.02.)","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"These instructions apply when there is evidence that the owner has, by his or her acts or omissions, affected the contractor's efficiency. They are to be used in conjunction with the other instructions relating to damages for breach of construction contract.    You have heard testimony that the Owner affected the Contractor's efficiency.  If you find that Owner's conduct affected the Contractor's efficiency, the Contractor may recover:       - a reasonable apportionment of the costs of any additional labor, equipment or materials it was reasonably required to employ; and    - a reasonable compensation for any additional productive effort or time reasonably required for the Contractor to perform the contract.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Owner conduct can reduce the effectiveness of the Contractor's work which may require additional work (inefficiency) by the Contractor.  Inefficiency costs are the ''extra\" or ''wasted\" costs incurred by the Contractor, which can include extra costs to perform work that the Contractor could have performed more efficiently but for the Owner's conduct.   You are instructed that if you return a verdict for the Contractor, the measure of the Contractor's damages for inefficiency is the additional or increased costs, if any, that the Contractor incurs as a result of the inefficiency.   The phrase ''extra'' cost includes any increase in cost and the phrase ''wasted'' cost includes both the cost and value of anything that has been spent, used up, or gone to nothing.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: How should a jury apply Affirmative Defenseâ€”Statute of Limitationsâ€”Latent Construction Defect (Code Civ. Proc., Â§ 337.15)?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When you decide liability, you should consider the statute of limitations for a latent construction defect pursuant to Code of Civil Procedure section 337.15. Under this statute, a construction-related defect claim must be commenced no later than ten years after substantial completion of an improvement to real property, or within one year after the plaintiff discovered or should have discovered the defect, whichever occurs first. For purposes of this time period, a latent defect is one which is not discoverable by reasonable inspection. This statute applies to latent defects in original construction of an improvement to real property and to latent defects in repair, replacement or remediation of a prior construction defect that were performed by the original builder.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The law provides that before you may find the defendant liable for damages, you first must find that the plaintiff has complied with all requirements of Civil Code section 895 et seq. In addition to the requirements of Civil Code section 895 et seq., the plaintiff also has to prove that it either provided the required written notice within the time required by statute, or that the defendant is estopped from relying on the statute of limitations because it prevented or discouraged the plaintiff from giving the required notice.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When you are deciding whether the statute of limitations has expired under an affirmative defense, you must determine the date when the plaintiff first knew, or reasonably should have known, the facts of the injury. You must then decide whether the plaintiff brought the lawsuit within the statutory deadline after that date.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The statute of limitations is the time within which you bring an action. An \"affirmative defense\" is a defense that you must state in your answer to the complaint, or that you have the burden of proving if you do not state it in your answer. The statute of limitations is an affirmative defense. If a plaintiff brings an action after the statutory time period has run, the action is barred by the statute of limitations. The statute of limitations bars an action unless it was started within the time period set by the statute after the cause of action accrued; that is, after the event giving rise to the cause of action occurred. Code of Civil Procedure section 337.15 sets forth the statute of limitations for a lawsuit alleging a latent construction defect. This statute of limitations restricts, to within 10 years after a new home is originally purchased from a builder; the time period within which certain actions based on a latent construction defect may be commenced against a builder by the original purchaser or certain other persons claiming an interest in the home.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you find that the plaintiff did not bring the action within the applicable limitations period, then the plaintiff has the burden to prove that the action was timely because of the \"discovery rule,\" discussed below. The Discovery Rule Section 337.15 contains a discovery rule exception to its one-year limitations period. Pursuant to the discovery rule, a plaintiff may bring an action within one year after the plaintiff discovered, or reasonably should have discovered, all of the following:         (1) that the injury described in subdivisions (f) to (i), inclusive, of section 337.15 has occurred;     (2) that the injury was proximately caused by the construction; and     (3) the identity of the party against whom the claim is asserted.        This discovery rule also applies to section 337.15 actions brought within the four-year or ten-year periods specified in subdivisions (f), (g), and (h), respectively.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: How should a jury apply Affirmative Defenseâ€”Work Completed and Acceptedâ€”Patent Defect?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"What is an affirmative defense? An affirmative defense is a defense in which the defendant presents new evidence and, if the jury believes it, will negate liability, even if it is proven that the defendant committed the alleged acts. Unless otherwise instructed, you should presume that the plaintiff has proved the issues of liability. The defendant has the burden to prove an affirmative defense by a preponderance of the evidence. This means that to succeed on an affirmative defense, the defendant must persuade you that it is more likely than not that the affirmative defense is true.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Under Massachusetts law, if a plaintiff seeks to recover for defective construction, the plaintiff may not recover damages if:(1) the work was completed and accepted by the plaintiff; (2) the defect was, or reasonably should have been, apparent to an inspection of the work at the time it was accepted; and (3) the defect became manifest within a reasonable time after acceptance. The same three conditions must be met for a plaintiff to recover damages for latent defects that were not discovered after reasonable inspection. On the other hand, a plaintiff may not recover damages for latent defects if:(1) the plaintiff did not make the defect manifest within a reasonable time after it became manifest or the plaintiff failed to take reasonable precautions against the consequences of the defect after it became manifest;(2) the defect was not a breach of contract; or(3) the contract specifically provided that the plaintiff waived the defects. This is Massachusetts Jury Instruction 18:19.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When a defendant proves this defense, the plaintiff cannot recover for damages based on a patent defect. A patent defect is one that was apparent from a reasonable examination of the work. If you find this defense successful, you should not award damages for a patent defect.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The Patent Defect affirmative defense is a complete defense. In order to establish this defense you must prove the following by a preponderance of the evidence:        (1) The work involved in the building or other improvement was defective; and    (2) The defective work was a material cause of a loss, damage, or injury; and    (3) The way the work was used was consistent with the way in which it was intended to be used; and    (4) The person asserting the defense accepted the work, either expressly or by implication.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"MISTAKE OF FACT If the defendant has offered evidence to support the defense of Work Completed and Accepted in response to Plaintiff's claim for patent defect, you are instructed as follows: You must first decide whether the work, or part of the work, in question was completed. If you find that the work was not completed, then your inquiry ends and you must find against the defendant on this defense. If you find that the work was completed, you must next decide whether the completed work was then accepted by the government. \"Accept\" or \"accepted\" as used in this instruction, means the following: The completed work was officially received and recognized by the government as conforming to the requirements of the contract, or if it did not conform, then the government had a reasonable opportunity to return the work or require re-performance according to the requirements of the contract but nevertheless opted not to do so. If you find that the completed work was not accepted, then your inquiry ends and you must find against the defendant on this defense. If you find that the completed work was accepted, then your inquiry continues. You must then decide whether the original contract contained an express agreement allocating the risk that certain specified conditions or circumstances might affect the work to be performed. You should consider all language contained in the original contract, including but not limited to language referring to inspections and acceptance. If you find that the original contract contained an express agreement allocating the risk that certain specified conditions or circumstances might affect the work to be performed, then your inquiry continues. You must next decide whether the alleged defective condition was within the class of conditions or circumstances for which the risk was allocated. If you find that the alleged defective condition was within the class of conditions or circumstances for which the risk was allocated, then you must find for the defendant on this defense. If you find that the alleged defective condition was not within the class of conditions or circumstances for which the risk was allocated, then you must find against the defendant on this defense. If you find that the original contract did not contain an express agreement allocating the risk that certain specified conditions or circumstances might affect the work to be performed, you must find against the defendant on this defense. If you do find in favor of the defendant on this affirmative defense, it does not affect your determination of whether the defect at issue was latent or patent.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

Latta, 235 N.C. 1, 68 S.E.2d 292 (1952) - When a general contractor accepts work done by subcontractor, the subcontractor cannot bas the quality of his work on a breach of contract action against the general contractor. Queen v. Fletcher, 317 Pa. 283, 176 A. 111 (1934) - An acceptance can be concluded from acts and circumstances. Union State Bank v. Erie Ins. Exchange, 299 Pa. Super. 465, 445 A.2d 653 (1982) - When a party does that which is contemplated by the contract as a condition precedent to the acquiring of some right or some other thing by the party, it amounts to an acceptance in law. American Insurance Company v. Keith, 194 Ark. 940, 110 SW2d 879 (1937) - Acceptance of a water tank serves to waive the notice of a patent defect. Satira v. Failure to Complain or Opportunity to Inspect a Work Constitutes a Waiver America Online, Inc. v. Failure to Complain Within a Certain Time Requires Prompt Complaints Boulder General Hospital v. Flora Constr. Co. v. St. Louis Housing Authority, 570 S.W.2d 237 (Mo.App. 1978) - A provision in the contract that requires the owner to give notice to the contractor within five days is a reasonable time for notice. completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Recovery of Payments to Unlicensed Contractor-Essential Factual Elements (Bus. & Prof. Code, Â§ 7031(b)) assists the jury in determining the plaintiff's entitlement to recover monies paid to an unlicensed contractor in certain threeparty situations. Three different threeparty situations are set forth in this statute, the factual elements of which are identical except that the two \"parties\" change. Thus, for instance, the parties may be a homeowner, the contractor and a subcontractor; a homeowner, the contractor and a mortgage lender; or an owner or tenant of a property, the contractor and a mortgage lender. In order for a party to recover monies paid to an unlicensed contractor, he or she must prove that all of the elements of one of these threeparty situations is present in the case.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}
